Student organizations run the gamut from Advancing Women In Science to Culinary Medicine Interest. The Greek Life community has over 20 men's and women's organizations.
Notable UNM alumni include Gary Johnson, former New Mexico governor and Libertarian Party presidential candidate and Pro Football Hall of Famer Brian Urlacher.
name: University of New Mexico

description:
An hour away from Indianapolis in Muncie, Indiana, Ball State University is a large public research university.
BSU has seven colleges, including the Teachers College and the Estopinal College of Architecture and Planning.
Biology, communications and nursing are among the most popular majors.
BSU is deeply entrenched in the Hoosier State, as 90% of the freshman class hails from Indiana and 70% of alumni remain in the state after graduation.
Talk show host and comedian David Letterman is a BSU alumnus. The Letterman Telecommunications Scholarship awards three telecommunications students a scholarship worth up to $10,000 and the David Letterman Communication and Media Building is named in his honor.
name: Ball State University

description:
Lehman College, an institution part of the City University of New York system located in the Bronx, is a liberal arts college with ample research opportunities.
Undergraduates can choose from 80 majors and programs. Popular programs include nursing, business administration and psychology.
Lehman boasts research strengths in a range of areas, including anthropology, biological sciences, chemistry, mathematics, computer science, psychology and physics and astronomy. The Science Hall was the first CUNY building to be awarded LEED Platinum certification, the highest sustainability ranking.
The student body’s diversity is reflective of the city it is located in. Over 50% of students are first-generation, and more than half of the student body identifies as Hispanic/Latino. The majority of students hail from the Bronx and other New York City boroughs.
Notable alumni include New York State Attorney General Letitia James and Bronx Borough President Rubén Díaz, Jr.
name: CUNY, Lehman College

description:
Located in Queens, NY, St. John’s University is a Catholic institution that aims to help students make their mark through service and gaining a global perspective.
The university offers 59 majors for students to choose from. Programs in the business school are most popular, followed by biology and criminal justice.
At St. John’s, students are encouraged to participate in community service, including at various events and partner programs the university hosts. Every year, the university holds University Service Day, when community members participate in different social justice and poverty organizations.
Approximately 42% of students study abroad in a variety of programs including global campuses in Paris; Rome, Italy; and Limerick, Ireland.
St. John’s gave out $417 million in undergraduate financial aid in the 2019-20 academic year. The university offers some special scholarships, such as a $3,000 per year award for students who graduated from a Catholic high school and $2,000 per year scholarships for children of police officers, firefighters and military service members.
name: St. John's University (NY)

description:
SUNY Maritime in Throggs Neck, NY, is part of the State University of New York system and is one of six maritime colleges in the country.
SUNY Maritime offers 10 bachelor of engineering and bachelor of science programs.
Students have the option of studying for a Merchant Marine license issued by the U.S. Coast Guard by joining the Regiment of Cadets. Part of this curriculum requires a Summer Sea Term, where cadets travel around the world gaining hands-on experience in operating a ship and dealing with port traffic. Civilian students must complete an internship in lieu of the summer sea term for license programs.
Students take part in over 70 student organizations and has 13 NCAA Division III teams, men's rowing and a co-ed sailing team.
Alumni include astronaut Scott Kelly and U.S. Navy Cmdr. Kevin Mannix.
name: SUNY Maritime College

description:
Among the fastest growing universities in the country, Rowan University is a public institution in Glassboro, NJ.
The school was known as Glassboro State College until 1992, when businessman Henry Rowan donated $100 million to the institution, which thereby changed its name to Rowan University.
Students with an adjusted gross family income of $45,000 or less receive free tuition through the Rowan University Opportunity Program.
Rowan’s Edelman Fossil Park is home to thousands of fossils, providing an in-depth glimpse into the Cretaceous Period.
The $5 million Rowan Innovation Venture Fund provides early-stage funding to startups from Rowan students, faculty and others associated with the university.
name: Rowan University

description:
Boasting one of the lowest student-faculty ratios at eight-to-one, Lawrence University is a three-term liberal arts college and music conservatory in Appleton, WI.
Lawrence offers 39 majors for students to pursue, including a bachelor of music arts that was introduced in 2020. Many students at the university study music performance, while economics, psychology and biology are also popular.
During a two-week “D-term” in December, students can take an intensive course with unique fieldwork or workshops, like “Soviet cooking culture” or the “science of super heroes.”
Within six months of graduating, 97% of Lawrence students find employment, enroll in graduate school or seek fellowship or service. The university has had 58 students who became Fulbright Scholars between 1976 and 2020.
About 99% of students receive some kind of financial aid, and 75% of students receive need-based assistance.
name: Lawrence University

description:
With its main campus located in Turlock, CA, about 100 miles East of San Francisco, California State University, Stanislaus has high marks as a green school and its commitment to the environment in practice and in the classroom.
There are 42 majors at Stan State. Business, psychology and criminal justice are the most popular programs.
There are about 150 scholarships available to incoming and continuing students, including many that fall within academic disciplines and departments.
Stan State has more than 80 student-led clubs on campus and 17 Greek life chapters. The Stanislaus State Warriors compete in 14 NCAA Division II teams.
Students are able to participate in short-term faculty-led study abroad programs or in a program with partner universities in New Zealand and Portugal.
name: California State University, Stanislaus

description:
A public research institution, Oakland University is located in Rochester MI, a Detroit suburb.
OU’s on-campus Golf & Learning Center features two 18-hole golf courses, a driving range and three putting greens. Students receive a heavily discounted rate to golf.
The Eye Research Institute Summer Undergraduate Program in Eye Research (SUPER) offers a unique opportunity for undergraduates to engage in ophthalmologic research. SUPER participants receive a research fellowship worth up to $4,250.
44% of students receive need-based financial aid and 75% of students receive some form of aid.
99% of employed OU graduates remain in Michigan.
name: Oakland University

description:
Located at the hills of the San Bernardino mountains, California State University, San Bernardino is a large public university that caters primarily to California residents.
Undergraduates can choose from over 70 programs across five colleges, including the popular College of Natural Sciences, College of Social and Behavioral Sciences and College of Business and Public Administration.
There are more than 160 clubs and organizations, including Greek life and Division I athletics, on campus. CSUSB also has a campus about an hour and a half away in Palm Desert.
The university is equipped with simulation laboratories, a television studio, an electronic music studio, glass blowing facilities, a Geographic Information Systems Lab and a crime analysis lab, where students can apply what they’ve learned in the classroom.
Over 80% of students are first-generation, and fewer than 1% are from out-of-state. Upwards of 60% are Hispanic/Latino.
name: California State University, San Bernardino

description:
The Florida Institute of Technology in Melbourne—also known as the state’s STEM university—offers hands-on experiences to prepare students for careers in science and technology.
Undergraduates can choose from over 70 majors on campus, as well as through FIT’s online programs. Popular programs include mechanical engineering, aerospace engineering and aeronautical science. Florida Tech's FastTrack master's degree program gives students the opportunity to take graduate-level courses during their undergraduate career.
Research is at the backbone of the FIT experience. The campus has 16 research centers, and the new Health Sciences Research Center is currently under construction and is set to be completed in December 2021.
Out-of-state U.S. students may earn university aid packages that cover up to 50% of tuition, and Florida students may be eligible for awards covering up to 100% of tuition and fees.
Approximately 95% of recent graduates are employed or pursuing further education.
name: Florida Institute of Technology

description:
A small private Christian college in Nashville, TN, Lipscomb University is located five miles south of Downtown Nashville.
Accounting, Biology and Nursing are among the university’s most popular majors.
Lipscomb does not have national fraternity or sororities, but does have Greek letter social clubs, which drive campus social life.
Faith and service are strongly emphasized at Lipscomb, and students log 60,000 volunteer service hours each year.
True to the school’s Nashville location, Lipscomb has produced some of the biggest stars in country music. Singers Thomas Rhett and Kelsea Ballerini are both Lipscomb alumni.
name: Lipscomb University

description:
Sewanee — University of the South, commonly known as Sewanee, is a liberal arts institution affiliated with the Episcopal Church that spans 13,000 acres of forests, lakes, meadows and caves in Sewanee, TN.
Sewanee offers 38 undergraduate majors, as well as pre-professional programs in business, law and medicine. The most popular majors are economics, English literature and international studies.
About 50% of students study abroad in more than 200 programs in all seven continents.
Sewanee pledges to fund students’ summer internships and research fellowships to help them secure a job or graduate school enrollment. The university also guarantees students will graduate within four years or be given an additional year of study tuition-free.
Sewanee has educated 26 Rhodes Scholars and two dozen Fulbright Scholars.
name: Sewanee—University of the South

description:
Weber State University is a public university in Ogden, UT with flexible programs that serve both traditional and non-traditional students.
WSU has more than 100 undergraduate programs across seven schools. The university also has centers across the state and more than 25 online degree and certificate programs. Popular programs are in the School of Nursing, School of Computing and School of Radiologic Sciences.
Students take part in almost 100 clubs, Greek life and Division I sports. The Outdoor Program provides rentals for outdoor gear and guided excursions. Campus is about a half hour away both from a ski resort and Salt Lake City.
Over 90% of students hail from Utah. About half of Weber’s awarded degrees are associate’s degrees, and over 50% of students attend part-time.
Weber gives more than $90 million in financial aid and scholarships annually. Non-resident students living within 100 highway miles of WSU are eligible to apply for a tuition reduction, and the university is a member of the Western Undergraduate Exchange program, which provides reduced tuition for students from select states.
name: Weber State University

description:
Presbyterian College is a small private school located in Clinton, SC, roughly halfway between Columbia and Greenville.
There are 42 majors at Presbyterian, including pre-pharmacy Biology and Chemistry options, both of which send many students to Presbyterian’s School of Pharmacy.
More than 40% of students are in Greek life, and Presbyterian’s fraternities and sororities are among the oldest in the country, dating back to 1890.
Presbyterian awards a variety of scholarships, including the Alumni Referral and Legacy Scholarships, both of which are renewable $1,000 grants over four years.
The Presbyterian Blue Hose compete in NCAA’s Division I. The unique Blue Hose nickname comes from the blue socks Presbyterian athletes wore in the early 1900s.
name: Presbyterian College

description:
Middle Tennessee State University is a large public university in Murfreesboro, TN, that’s known for its music production program and affordable tuition.
Students at MTSU can choose from more than 60 majors across 7 different colleges. The most popular programs are in business, visual and performing arts and communications.
There are more than 350 student groups on campus for students to engage in.
MTSU is home to the Department of Recording Industry, a leading music production program that trains students in audio production and songwriting. Graduates from the Recording Industry program have gone on to work with musicians including Keith Urban, Kacey Musgraves and Bruce Springsteen.
First-time freshmen are eligible for merit scholarships based on GPA and standardized testing scores.
name: Middle Tennessee State University

description:
Farmingdale State College is a mid-sized member of the State University of New York system on Long Island.
The university offers 40 bachelor’s degree programs, ranging from Aeronautical Science to Sustainable Agriculture.
In response to New York’s passage of the Marijuana Regulation and Taxation Act, Farmingdale State recently introduced a certificate program in Cannabis Production and Management for students.
Farmingdale State’s student body is home-grown: about 90% of students hail from Long Island’s Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
The Farmingdale State alumni network is more than 100,000 strong, including former NASA Astronaut Fernando Caldeiro.
name: SUNY, Farmingdale State College

description:
The first institution of higher education in Texas, Southwestern University in Georgetown is a small, private university with an interdisciplinary liberal arts curriculum.
Students can choose from over 30 majors. Popular programs include business, psychology, biology and political science. SU is one of only a handful of undergraduate liberal arts universities that support a separate school of fine arts.
The intimate community is bustling, with over 90 student organizations, including Greek life. SU, just 30 minutes from Austin, has faculty-led programs in countries like Buenos Aires, Amsterdam and London, as well as study-away study and internship options in New York and Washington, D.C.
The Brown Scholarship is Southwestern’s most prestigious and competitive award and is valued at $35,000 per year. General merit scholarships range up to $28,500 annually.
Approximately 61% of the Class of 2020 is employed—the majority of which remained in Texas—and 24% are pursuing advanced degrees.
name: Southwestern University

description:
Siena is a private college in Loudonville, NY, whose teachings are rooted in a Franciscan, liberal arts tradition.
Siena offers almost 40 majors. Popular programs include marketing, psychology and accounting. As part of its core curriculum, students take courses in Franciscan heritage, diversity, social justice and nature.
About 70% of students take part in hands-on experiences, like research and internships. The Stewarts Advanced Instrumentation and Technology Center, or SAInT Center, partners students with leaders in scientific instrumentation to provide training, research and educational opportunities.
There are more than 100 student organizations at Siena, including Division I sports, but no Greek life.
On average, “Saints” receive $23,000 from Siena. Students are automatically considered for academic scholarships. The Saint Francis Scholarship awards up to $12,000 over four years and is for residents from New York and border states.
About 90% of recent graduates are employed or continuing their education.
name: Siena College

description:
Saint Mary’s University of Minnesota is a small, Catholic liberal arts college in Winona, MN, that emphasizes ethics and leadership.
Students at Saint Mary’s can choose from more than 40 majors that range from the liberal arts to professional programs in nursing, secondary education and ministry. Saint Mary’s also offers a 3+2 physician assistant program, and a 4+1 master’s in education program.
For nontraditional undergraduates with partial degrees, Saint Mary’s offers a flexible online completion program.
There are more than 40 clubs and organizations on campus for students to join, including two Greek life chapters dedicated to music and performance.
Notable Saint Mary’s alumni include former Nebraska Governor and U.S. Senator Mike Johanns and Chicago Blackhawks CEO John McDonough.
name: Saint Mary's University of Minnesota

description:
Centre College is a small private liberal arts school in Danville, KY, the geographic center of the state.
The “Centre Commitment” ensures that students can study abroad, complete an internship and graduate in four years. If they do not complete all three (and meet certain other requirements), the school provides up to a year of free tuition.
Centre is home to one of the top glass-blowing studios in the nation.
The college recently announced plans for a $50 million wellness and athletic center, the largest construction project in Centre history. The facility will feature a 50-meter swimming pool, an indoor track and turf infield and more, with construction slated to begin this fall.
Centre counts two United States vice presidents, Adlai Stevenson and John C. Breckinridge, among its alumni.
name: Centre College

description:
The University of Wyoming is situated by the Rocky Mountains in the city of Laramie, about two hours away from Denver, CO. It is the only four-year university in Wyoming’s state school system.
The university offers more than 80 majors. The most popular programs are in business, engineering and education.
Students can choose from more than 400 study abroad programs in 80 countries.
UW awards students merit scholarships to in-state, out-of-state, transfer and international students. Domestic students can apply to the school test optional and, starting fall 2021, may be awarded merit scholarships without submitting test scores.
There are more than 300 student organizations on campus, including 21 sports clubs and 16 Greek life organizations, as well as partnerships with many local community service organizations.
name: University of Wyoming

description:
Utah Valley University is a large public school in Orem, UT, that operates with a unique “dual mission” model to combine the resources and rigor of a major university with the accessibility of a community college.
UVU’s dual mission and origins as a vocational school are reflected in its student body: 80% of students work while enrolled, 30% are over 25 years old and 37% are first generation.
Students at UVU can choose from 90 undergraduate degrees, with popular programs in business, psychology and visual and performing arts.
The UVU Wolverines compete in NCAA Division 1 athletics in the Western Athletic Conference. Students can join a range of groups from hiking clubs to a rodeo team.
Incoming freshmen who graduated high school with a GPA of 3.9 or higher, and who have high standardized testing scores can qualify for the full tuition Presidential Scholarship.
name: Utah Valley University

description:
Long Island University is a large private university in Brookville, NY, that offers a wide variety of in-person, online and nonresidential courses. It has a second main campus in Brooklyn.
Students at LIU can pursue 49 majors, ranging from professional programs in veterinary technology and pharmacy to liberal arts degrees in film and English. Its nursing and healthcare programs are particularly popular.
Greek life is central to the residential experience at LIU’s Brookville campus, though the school has removed 17 chapters since 2010.
National Merit Scholars are considered for the full tuition Provost’s Award for Scholastic Excellence. There are also a number of scholarships for students transferring from Long Island community colleges.
Notable LIU alumni include Fox News anchor Brian Kilmeade, former Yahoo CEO Terry Semel and billionaire hedge fund manager Ray Dalio.
name: LIU Post

description:
One of the oldest and most prestigious historically Black colleges and universities, Spelman is a private, women’s liberal arts college in Atlanta, GA, that is dedicated to fostering leadership and intellectual creativity in its students.
Spelman offers 33 majors, as well as the opportunity for an Independent Study major and a dual degree program in engineering. It also offers special academic programs focused on the African diaspora, art and curatorial studies, Asian studies, and food studies.
Campus life at Spelman is vibrant. 1,200 students live on campus in 11 distinct residence halls, where they participate in over 85 student groups, including Greek life. Students can opt to live in Living & Learning Communities dedicated to social justice, scholarship, public service and leadership.
Graduates of Spelman are passionate about furthering their education: One third of alumni go on to graduate or professional school in their first year after graduating.
Notable Spelman alumni include Pulitzer Prize winner Alice Walker, politician Stacey Abrams and Walgreens Boots Alliance CEO Rosalind Brewer.
name: Spelman College

description:
Illinois Wesleyan University focuses on giving students a broad liberal arts education with opportunities to learn outside of the classroom. The campus spans 82 acres north of downtown Bloomington, mid-way between Chicago and St. Louis.
There are 38 majors for students to choose from, as well as eight pre-professional programs. Nursing is the most popular major, closely followed by accounting. Students can choose to study a course outside the normal curriculum during a one-month May term in the classroom or abroad.
There are around 120 clubs on campus, including nine fraternity and sorority chapters. About 71% of students complete an internship by the time they graduate. The university has a 91% first-year retention rate, and 95% of graduates are employed or attend graduate school within six months.
More than 95% of students receive some form of financial aid, which covers over half of tuition on average. The university offers scholarships of up to $35,000 for fine arts majors and a scholarship package of at least $30,000 for students from McLean County.
name: Illinois Wesleyan University

description:
As one of the first liberal arts colleges with a criminal-justice focus, the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in the City University of New York system prepares students for serving the public.
John Jay offers 41 undergraduate majors — the most popular being criminal justice, forensic psychology and criminology — and 16 master’s programs across 24 departments and four programs. Students are also able to participate in research opportunities with faculty.
The college serves a diverse population; it is classified as a Hispanic Serving Institution and a Minority Serving Institution, nearly 50% of students are first-generation, over 50% identify as Hispanic or African American and there are more than 500 veterans enrolled. John Jay also has the Prisoner Reentry Institute to support current and formerly incarcerated students.
There are over 50 student organizations, many of which are cultural or academic, and no Greek life. John Jay is located in Midtown Manhattan, making it convenient for students to explore all that New York City has to offer. The majority of alumni go on to careers in government and nonprofit organizations, and 50% work in public service.
Henry Lee, a forensic scientist who worked on the O. J. Simpson trial and the reinvestigation of the John F. Kennedy assassination, attended the college
organizationName: CUNY, John Jay College of Criminal Justice
name: CUNY, John Jay College of Criminal Justice

description:
Fairleigh Dickinson is a large, private university with campuses in Madison and Teaneck, NJ, and satellite campuses in England and Toronto.
Students can pursue a traditional, residential college experience at the Florham campus in Madison, NJ, or a career-focused, urban experience at the Metropolitan campus in Teaneck and Hackensack, NJ.
There are 27 programs for undergraduates to choose from, including liberal arts programs and pre-professional degrees in fields like homeland security and hospitality.
The school’s New Jersey campuses support more than 140 student groups and clubs, as well as Greek Life. The FDU Knights compete in 21 NCAA D1 sports.
Notable FDU alumni include conservative commentator Peggy Noonan, Home Depot cofounder Ron Brill and billionaire co-owner of the Minnesota Vikings Zygi Wilf.
name: Fairleigh Dickinson University

description:
Thomas Jefferson is a small, private research university in Philadelphia, PA, that specializes in interdisciplinary career readiness.
Students at TJU choose a course of study from one of 8 different focus areas: Architecture, design, fashion and textiles, science, business, engineering, health and social science.
Originally founded as a medical school, Thomas Jefferson continues its tradition of research with robust opportunities for undergraduates, like the Summer Undergraduate Research program, which partners students with faculty researchers in fields like neuroscience and tissue engineering.
There are 70 clubs and organizations for students to get involved in at TJU, including Greek life.
96% of undergraduates at Thomas Jefferson receive financial aid.
name: Thomas Jefferson University

description:
California State University, Channel Islands, is a midsize public university in Camarillo, CA, that is the youngest member of the California State University system.
Students at CSUCI can choose from majors in 27 fields of study, with popular programs in business, psychology and healthcare professional services.
Half of CSUCI’s student body is Hispanic, and the school was designated a Hispanic Serving Institution in 2010.
Students at CSUCI can make the most of its coastal surroundings with free recreational opportunities at the Channel Islands Boating Center. The university also maintains a research station on the Channel Islands that monitors seacliff erosion, wetland water quality and stream restoration.
83% of students at CSUCI receive financial aid.
name: California State University, Channel Islands

description:
Located in Boone, NC, in the Blue Ridge Mountains, Appalachian State University seeks to create a sustainable community and give students a range of academic opportunities.
The university offers around 170 majors for students to pursue. The most popular programs are in exercise science, psychology and elementary education.
More than 40% of undergraduates participate in an academic internship each year. Undergraduates are also allowed to partake in stipend-funded research assistantships during the fall and spring semesters.
There are more than 400 student clubs on campus, including 32 Greek life organizations.
The university awards 50 North Carolina students from low-income families the ACCESS Scholarship, which allows them to attend the school debt-free. The university also gives many merit scholarships and departmental academic scholarships.
name: Appalachian State University

description:
The only residential public university in the mid-Hudson region, SUNY, College at New Paltz offers over 50 undergraduate majors, ranging from business to communications to education to fine arts. New majors include environmental studies and entrepreneurship.
The First-Year Internship Program allows freshmen to complete an internship during their second semester of college.
There are more than 200 student organizations, and the campus is equipped with a planetarium and an art museum. About 40% of all new first-year and transfer students at New Paltz in Fall 2021 represent underrepresented demographic groups, including about 25% of incoming students who identify as Hispanic. About 95% of incoming students are from New York.
New Paltz has a limited number of merit scholarships, and no additional application is required. The college offers the #YouAreWelcomeHere scholarship, which covers half of tuition for international students.
After a decade-plus tenure as president, Donald P. Christian is set to retire in June 2022.
name: SUNY, College at New Paltz

description:
Located about a half hour outside of Boston, UMass Lowell is a public research university committed to robust learning both inside and outside of the classroom.
UMass Lowell offers over 120 undergraduate majors across five colleges. Popular programs include business administration, psychology and mechanical engineering.
The university has over $84 million in research expenditures and provides $2,500 stipends through its research programs for students in the College of Fine Arts, Humanities, and Social Sciences and the Manning School of Business.
UMass Lowell has over 250 student organizations, including Greek life and Division I athletics.
The university offers a number of full-tuition awards for Massachusetts residents. Out of state students can receive awards ranging up to $20,000. The Immersive Scholar program awards incoming freshmen with $4,000 to engage in research, studying abroad or work with the community.
name: University of Massachusetts Lowell

description:
Part of the University of Wisconsin system, the University of Wisconsin, La Crosse is known for its biology and beer.
Biology is the most popular major at UW-La Crosse, and biology students can choose from a variety of unique academic concentrations, such as aquatic science, biomedical science and plant and fungal biology. Of the 45 undergraduate fields of study, other popular programs include healthy and physical education and finance.
This fall will mark La Crosse’s 60th Oktoberfest, one of the largest Oktoberfest celebrations in the U.S.
UW-La Crosse students stay active—87% of students participate in intramural sports.
Chef and television personality Sandra Lee and Green Bay Packers general manager Brian Gutekunst are both UW-La Crosse alumni.
name: University of Wisconsin, La Crosse

description: The University of St. Thomas in Houston, TX blends the Catholic faith with a comprehensive educational experience. Undergraduate students can choose from nearly 40 majors, including STEM, nursing, education and premed. UST also offers 24 graduate degrees. UST’s core curriculum exposes students to a range of disciplines from mathematics to theology.  About 65% of freshmen practice the Catholic faith; the chapel hosts mass every day. Beyond the academic, honor and faith-based clubs, students can also take part in recreational trips throughout Texas, like horseback riding and wakeboarding, or campus ministry retreats. The Celts are provisional members in the NCAA Division III and accepted membership in the Southern Collegiate Athletic Conference. The university also prides itself on its diversity; about 68% of the student body are nonwhite, and 58 other countries are represented. UST’s business office offers a 0% interest monthly payment plan for tuition, and more than 96% of full-time freshmen receive a scholarship.
name: University of St. Thomas (TX)

description:
The University of Toledo is a public research institution that takes advantage of the city’s resources to provide students with a comprehensive educational experience.
UToledo has a wide range of offerings on campus and online, with more than 200 undergraduate and graduate degree programs across the arts, business, education, engineering, law, medicine, natural sciences, nursing and pharmacy.
Research specialities include astronomy and astrophysics; solar energy, water quality and sustainable technology; and cell architecture and dynamics. The university boasts more than $50 million in research dollars.
Over 60% of graduates report that they participated in experiential learning during their time at UToledo. The university partners with several Fortune 500 companies, whose headquarters are in the city, to provide students with research, internship and employment opportunities.
Undergraduates are guaranteed a fixed rate for tuition and fees over four years. About 80% of new undergraduates receive scholarships.
name: University of Toledo

description:
Transylvania University is a tiny school with a big history in downtown Lexington, KY. It was founded in 1780, and its name means “across the woods” in Latin.
One hundred percent of Transy’s students attend full-time, nearly half are members of a fraternity or sorority, and 99% receive scholarships or grants.
Out of 34 fields of study offered, the most popular majors include business, biology, psychology and accounting.
After the conclusion of the spring semester, Transylvania enters the four-week May Term, which students often use as an opportunity to study abroad.
Don’t expect to find Count Dracula lurking around campus, but Transylvania does embrace its vampire ties: the Transylvania Theater put on a production of “Carmilla: A Vampiress Radio Play” this spring.
name: Transylvania University

description:
As the nation’s first college dedicated to environmental sustainability, SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry in Syracuse, NY, lives up to its name with education and research opportunities in the field.
Many undergraduate students conduct research in fields from bioenergy to wildlife disease prevention.
There are 23 majors for students to choose from, including aquatic and fisheries science, paper engineering, and conservation biology.
SUNY-ESF offers several merit scholarships, including National Hispanic Scholarships, transfer student scholarships, and the Haudenosaunee Scholar Award for members of a Haudenosaunee nation.
Due to its proximity to Syracuse University, SUNY-ESF students are able to take courses, join clubs and use the facilities at the university.
organizationName: SUNY, College of Environmental Science and Forestry
name: SUNY, College of Environmental Science and Forestry

description:
Located in the Dorchester neighborhood, the University of Massachusetts, Boston is the only public research university in Boston.
UMass Boston’s campus is three miles from downtown, tucked away on the waterfront next to the John F. Kennedy Library and Presidential Museum.
The 220,000-square-foot Integrated Sciences Complex features numerous science research laboratories, including an infant cognition lab and the Center for Personalized Cancer Therapy.
UMass Boston opened the doors to its first-ever residence hall, which cost $120 million and has more than 1,000 beds, in 2018.
Notable UMass Boston alumni include former ​​New York City Police Commissioner William Bratton and fashion designer Joseph Abboud.
name: University of Massachusetts Boston

description:
Northern Illinois University is a large public university in DeKalb, IL, that offers a wide range of liberal arts and professional courses.
Students at NIU can choose from over 100 majors, as well as a large number of accelerated programs that deliver a bachelor’s degree along with a master’s or law degree.
NIU has a lively campus: Students can live in one of 5 large dormitories and participate in over 300 clubs and organizations. The NIU Huskies participate in the NCAA D1 Mid-American conference.
All NIU students are automatically considered for merit scholarships, which are awarded to students with high GPAs. Students are also considered for the prestigious Presidential Scholars award, which covers full tuition.
Notable NIU alumni include “Simpsons” voice actor Dan Castellaneta, “The Wire” actor Wood Harris and U.S. Senator Tammy Duckworth.
name: Northern Illinois University

description:
With an undergraduate enrollment of 1,400, the University of Dallas provides a tight-knit Catholic liberal arts education that is accepting of all faiths. The campus is about ten miles from downtown Dallas.
The university offers 25 areas of study, as well as many non-major concentrations. The core curriculum consists of 19 courses in English, theology, natural sciences, social sciences and foreign languages.
Students can choose to study abroad in modern language or science programs. Many students also participate in UD’s Rome semester programs.
All incoming freshmen are automatically considered for merit scholarships ranging from $15,000 to $30,000 annually. There is also a scholarship for students who attend Catholic high schools in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
There are around 45 clubs and organizations for students to join, including science and humanities clubs, advocacy groups and nine sports and recreation clubs.
name: University of Dallas

description:
Despite being one of the largest universities in the state, the University of North Carolina, Charlotte provides students with individualized experiences through a robust curriculum.
Undergraduates can choose from over 170 majors across seven colleges. Popular programs include computer science, communication studies and health management.
The university has doubled its research expenditures over the last five years, and 90% of graduated students have participated in research or internships.
UNC Charlotte offers a number of merit scholarships, including the Levine Scholars, which covers the cost of attendance and four summer experiences, and major-specific awards like the Albert Engineering Leadership Scholars Program and the Belk Scholars Program in Business Analytics.
About 84% of the class of 2020 are either employed or in graduate school, with the majority remaining in North Carolina.
name: University of North Carolina, Charlotte

description:
Western Michigan University is a large public school in Kalamazoo, MI.
About 75% of WMU classes will be held in person this fall. The university is awarding 60 scholarships of up to $10,000 to students who provide documentation of their vaccination against Covid.
In June, a group of WMU alumni made a $550 million donation to their alma mater. The Empowering Futures Gift will go towards need-based financial assistance, diversity in medicine and student-athletes' academic performance.
Accounting, criminal justice and nursing are among WMU’s most popular majors.
WMU is the alma mater of a pair of famous comedic actors: Tim Allen, who received an honorary doctorate from the school, and Terry Crews, who starred on the WMU football team and starred in Everybody Hates Chris and Brooklyn Nine-Nine.
name: Western Michigan University

description:
Suffolk is a midsize private research university in downtown Boston known for its strong programs in business and law.
Students at Suffolk can choose from 45 majors offered at the College of Art & Science and the Sawyer Business School. The university’s history as a law school is apparent in its undergraduate offerings, with majors including paralegal studies and policy & law.
Suffolk has a number of programs to develop leadership, notably “The Journey,” a four-year program that emphasizes service and global thinking.
More than 80 student clubs and organizations are active at Suffolk, including Greek life.
Notable Suffolk alumni include U.S. Representative John Tierney and Marty Meehan, the president of the University of Massachusetts.
name: Suffolk University

description:
Georgia Southern University is a patriotic public university in Statesboro, GA.
Known as the Eagle Battalion, the Georgia Southern ROTC program is one of the top ROTC units in the country, receiving the MacArthur Award four times. The school is also one of the top producers of military nurses in the country.
Exercise Science is one of Georgia Southern’s most popular majors, offering concentrations in fields such as inclusive physical activity, sport performance and pre-physical therapy. Other popular fields of study are business administration and biology.
Continuing in the patriotic spirit, the university’s official mascot is a live American Bald Eagle.
Country music star Luke Bryan is a Georgia Southern alumnus, majoring in business administration and starting his music career in Statesboro venues.
name: Georgia Southern University

description:
The University of Minnesota, Crookston, is a small, public university in the town of Crookston in northwest Minnesota.
Students at UM Crookston can choose from 35 majors (one of which, applied health, is only available online). Aspiring farmers can study agricultural business and management, agronomy, animal science, equine science and horticulture.
Half of Crookston’s student body takes classes online.Two thirds of the 900 students that study in-person live on campus, where they can participate in 40 student clubs and Division 2 athletics.
Freshmen who are Minnesota residents can make the most of the “Minnesota Promise,” which covers tuition for families whose annual income is below $50,000. The Berland Opportunity Grant provides funding for nontraditional students who are returning to school after four or more years.
Michael Chowdry, the founder of Atlas Air cargo carriers, was an alumnus of UM Crookston.
name: University of Minnesota-Crookston

description:
Duquesne University in Pittsburgh, PA is the only Spiritan Catholic institution of higher education in the United States.
Undergraduates can choose from about 80 majors across eight colleges, as well as pre-med and pre-law programs and combined degree programs. Duquesne also has campuses in Rome and Dublin.
The Undergraduate Research and Scholarship Symposium is held each spring and encourages undergraduates from all areas of study to engage in research.
There are more than 250 student organizations at Duquesne, and numerous cultural and nightlight opportunities in Pittsburgh. About 8,000 Duquesne students, faculty and staff participate in volunteer activities annually.
DU offers merit scholarships based on high school GPA, ranging up to $18,500. Other scholarship programs include the “Spirit of Community” Scholarship for students passionate about civic engagement and the National Hispanic Recognition Scholarship, a full-tuition award for the highest-ranked National Hispanic Scholar.
name: Duquesne University

description:
Monmouth is a midsize, private university in West Long Branch, NJ, that emphasizes small class sizes, a liberal arts curriculum and ongoing career support.
Students at Monmouth can choose from 43 different majors, as well as 70 different 5-year programs for bachelor’s and master’s degrees.
The Monmouth core curriculum requires all students to take a special course each year, which emphasize the liberal arts, global perspectives, ethics and conscientious citizenship.
There are many clubs and student groups on campus on Monmouth, from pre-professional organizations and cultural affinity groups to student media and Greek life.
Incoming students with GPAs of 3.6 or above are considered for one of four full tuition scholarships.
name: Monmouth University

description:
A small, Catholic school in Kansas City, MO, Rockhurst University offers students an intimate liberal arts education guided by Jesuit values.
Rockhurst’s 55-acre campus is a mile from the upscale Country Club Plaza and four miles south of downtown Kansas City. vAbout half of Rockhurst students are Catholic. Regardless of major, all undergraduates completed a core curriculum centered on the Jesuit ideal of a well-rounded education with requirements in the arts, scientific inquiry and global perspectives.
Roughly 40% of Rockhurst students are in the Bachelor of Science in Nursing degree program. Rockhurst nursing graduates report a $70,000 median salary and a 100% job placement rate.
More than half of Rockhurst alumni remain in the Kansas City metropolitan area.
name: Rockhurst University

description:
St. Bonaventure is a small, Catholic university in Allegany, NY, that stresses a liberal arts education and the Franciscan values of community, compassion and wisdom.
Students at St Bonaventure can choose from over 50 majors in the liberal arts or professional fields. The core curriculum requires coursework in the liberal arts, Franciscan ethics, writing and diversity.
The arts are strong at St. Bonaventure: The school’s Regina A. Quick Center for the Arts houses numerous galleries, a 300-seat theatre and vocal and instrumental labs.
Incoming freshmen with high academic achievement are eligible for a number of merit-based scholarships which can range up to $25,000 a year.
St. Bonaventure maintains affiliated study abroad programs in China, Spain, Italy and Japan.
name: St Bonaventure University

description:
The University of Redlands in Redlands, CA, is a private liberal arts school that aims to give students a personalized, unique college experience.
The university offers around 40 programs for undergraduates, and many students at Redlands study business. During “May Term,” students can take courses outside of the normal curriculum either on campus or abroad.
Students are required to engage in community service learning. Students and faculty volunteer 100,000 hours of service to nonprofits and partner organizations each year.
There are more than 100 student clubs on campus, including Greek life chapters that date back to the beginning of the school’s history.
About 94% of students found employment, enrolled in graduate school or pursued service within one year of graduating. Redlands has produced 24 Fulbright scholars, including three recipients in 2019.
name: University of Redlands

description:
California State University, Dominguez Hills, is a large public university in Carson, CA, known for its robust course offerings and diverse student body.
Students at CSU DH can choose to major at one of six colleges: arts and humanities; business administration and public policy; education; natural and behavioral sciences; health and nursing; and a distance learning program.
CSU DH is one of the most diverse schools in the California State University system: 11% of students are Black, and 66% identify as Hispanic. Nearly two-thirds of students are women.
More than 90 student organizations and clubs are housed at CSU DH. Students can easily start their own affinity groups with 5 members and a faculty adviser.
Notable CSU DH alumni include actor Niecy Nash and U.S. Representative Karen Bass.
name: California State University-Dominguez Hills

description:
One of the younger members of the California State University system, CSU Bakersfield is a midsize public university in Bakersfield, CA, that offers a personalized 18:1 student to faculty ratio.
CSU Bakersfield offers more than 55 undergraduate majors, including popular programs in business, psychology and law enforcement.
There are more than 100 student organizations at CSU Bakersfield, including Greek life.
The Bakersfield Roadrunners compete in 18 sports in the NCAA Division 1 Big West Conference.
Notable alumni include House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy and mixed martial artist Tito Ortiz.
name: California State University-Bakersfield

description: Founded in 1891 as the first public women’s college in the state, today the University of North Carolina, Greensboro is a coeducational research university. UNC Greensboro offers 125 undergraduate degree programs and more than 100 graduate degree programs. The most popular areas of study are in business, biology, health and visual and performing arts. The university is a research hub and receives more than $39 million in external funding for health, community and global connections initiatives. UNC Greensboro awards general scholarships based on both academic achievement and financial need. Individual departments also offer their own scholarships. More than 250 student organizations are active on campus, including 24 Greek chapters. Seventeen teams of Greensboro Spartans compete in the NCAA’s Division I Southern Conference. One long-held tradition finds students bringing apples to the campus statue of Minerva before exams for good luck. Alumni include singer songwriter Rhiannon Giddens, Olympic Medalist Paul Chelimo, actor Chris Chalk, and comedy writer Emily Spivey.
name: University of North Carolina, Greensboro

description:
Located in the heart of Tampa, FL, the University of Tampa is a mid-sized private school.
UT’s main academic and administrative building, Plant Hall, was originally a Victorian hotel and is supposedly haunted.
Finance, criminology and marketing are among the most popular majors.
UT emphasizes experiential learning and more than 700 students complete internships for credit each year.
Notable UT alumni include Florida’s first Hispanic mayor Bob Martinez, author Connie May Fowler and four-time World Series champion baseball player Tino Martinez.
name: University of Tampa

description:
California Lutheran University is a private institution in Thousand Oaks, CA, that is one of the few universities affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America.
Undergraduates can choose from over 40 majors. Popular programs include business administration, psychology and biology. Over half of students participate in an internship during their time at Cal Lutheran.
Students can take part in around 100 student organizations. The campus ministry hosts a weekly chapel service and additional faith-based programming.
Cal Lutheran has been designated a Hispanic-serving institution, and more than half of the undergraduate population identifies as non-white.
Students can earn awards up to full-tuition through the Presidential, Steven Dorfman and Transfer Achievement Scholarships. Cal Lutheran also offers talent, legacy and faith-based scholarships.
name: California Lutheran University

description:
The ArtCenter College of Design is a small, private art school in Pasadena, CA, that aims to combine key design principles with global thinking.
ArtCenter offers just 11 majors, with programs in product design, fine art, advertising and automotive design. Students looking for a well-rounded education can minor in business, creative writing and social innovation.
Scholarships are offered based on financial need and artistic and academic accomplishments. International students are considered for scholarships without recognition of financial need.
There are no dorms at ArtCenter, but the college works with students to find housing in Los Angeles.
Notable ArtCenter alumni include director Zack Snyder, Linkin Park musician Mike Shinoda and automobile designer Frank Stephenson.
name: Art Center College of Design

description:
Set in the rustic New England town of Willimantic, CT, Eastern Connecticut State University is a “green campus” public school, dedicated to sustainability in academic programming, practice and is the home of the Institute for Sustainable Energy.
After requiring all students to get vaccinated against Covid, Eastern’s campus is fully open this fall, with residence halls at full capacity and all classes being held in person.
90% of the Eastern student body hails from Connecticut, though students come from 34 other states and 19 foreign countries.
Though they still pay more than their Connecticut resident peers, other New England residents enjoy a $10,000 tuition discount at Eastern compared to other out-of-state students.
Notable Eastern alumni include Nigerian-American author Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, recipient of the MacArthur “genius” grant in 2008.
name: Eastern Connecticut State University

description:
A small, public technical school, the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology is located an hour outside of Albuquerque in Socorro, NM.
More than half of undergraduates are engineers.
NMT’s research is explosive. The Energetic Materials Research and Testing Center has more than 30 test sites and gun ranges, serving as a frequent filming location for Mythbusters.
The college does not have any varsity athletic teams, though campus is home to a bouldering wall and an 18-hole golf course.
NMT identifies as a STE²M school, the extra E standing for entrepreneurialism. Each year, the school hosts an Inventor and Entrepreneur Workshop to prepare its budding engineering and scientists for the business world.
organizationName: New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology
name: New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology

description:
Located in St. Paul, MN, Concordia University-Saint Paul is a Lutheran liberal arts school with a 17:1 student-faculty ratio.
CSP’s tuition is the lowest among the 17 members of the Minnesota Private College Council, partially thanks to a $10,000 tuition decrease in 2013.
The university’s 80+ academic programs range from Christian ministry to sport psychology. The two most popular fields of study are business administration and health and physical education.
The Church Work Tuition Guarantee ensures that participants in church work programs pay no more than $6,000 in tuition annually, preparing future Lutheran pastors, teachers and musicians.
The CSP women’s volleyball team is a Division II powerhouse, winning nine national championships since 2007.
name: Concordia University-Saint Paul

description:
Among the largest universities in the nation, Texas State University is located in San Marcos, Texas, less than an hour from Austin and San Antonio.
About 40% of Texas State students identify as Hispanic.
The university has received $48 million through Hispanic-Serving Institution funding from agencies such as the Department of Education, NASA and the USDA through since 2011.
Texas State offers more than 180 majors and minors, ranging from agriculture business management to southwestern studies.
President Lyndon B. Johnson was a Texas State alumnus, and he is commemorated on campus with a life-size statue and the LBJ Student Center.
name: Texas State University

description:
Abilene Christian University in Abilene, TX, is a private university that educates students for Christan service and leadership.
Undergraduates can choose from over 70 majors in the arts and sciences, business, education, nursing and biblical studies. ACU has a satellite campus in Addison, TX, which serves as the hub to the university’s online programs.
ACU offers study abroad opportunities with its faculty in Oxford, England; Montevideo, Uruguay; and Leipzig, Germany, and about 40% of students learn internationally. The university also provides faculty-guided funding to promote undergraduate research, up to $10,000.
Spiritual formation is a cornerstone of the ACU experience, and students are required to attend daily chapel services and practice Christian values, like chastity outside of marriage. Students also get involved in more than 100 student organizations, including Greek life, and global and domestic missions.
ACU has a block tuition system in which students can take up to 36 hours across the fall, spring and summer sessions for one price. Automatic merit awards range from $10,000 to $19,000 annually.
name: Abilene Christian University

description:
A public school, the University of Tennessee, Chattanooga has scenic views of the Tennessee River and nearby mountains.
About 20% of students major in the Gary W. Rollins College of Business. Other popular fields of study include education and nursing.
UTC offers a variety of scholarships, such as the $2,000 per semester HOPE Scholarship that draws upon proceeds from the state lottery or the $5,000 per year Chancellor’s Scholarship for students that scored a 29 or higher on the ACT.
With about one-third of students eligible for Pell Grants, three-quarters of students receive some form of financial assistance.
Pro Football Hall of Famer Terrell Owens and “Saved by the Bell” actor Dennis Haskins are both UT Chattanooga alumni.
name: The University of Tennessee-Chattanooga

description:
Located in Tacoma, WA, the University of Puget Sound is a private liberal arts school with ties to the United Methodist Church. A Puget Sound education emphasizes critical thinking and experiential learning.
Puget Sound has an eight-course core curriculum, consisting of two freshman seminars and additional courses in art, math, humanist, natural science and social sciences. The school is partnered with 250 local groups in Tacoma for community-based learning programs.
Business, Political Science and Psychology are amongst the school’s most popular majors.
The school’s Slater Museum of Natural History holds various species of birds, mammals, reptiles, amphibians and plant specimens from the Pacific Northwest.
Puget Sound is one of the top producers of Peace Corps volunteers, and the school offers a Peace Corps Prep certificate to prepare students for the program.
name: University of Puget Sound

description:
Founded by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, Brigham Young University-Idaho in Rexburg believes in developing students into community and Church leaders.
BYU-Idaho offers 77 majors for students to choose from. Courses are guided by a learning model where students complete work on their own time and participate in faculty-led discussions and activities in the classroom.
For a private university, BYU-Idaho’s tuition is among the lowest in the country, since the cost of enrollment is partially funded by the church. The university provides grants for internship expenses and grants for students who show talent in journalism or the arts.
The university encourages students to gain experience fulfilling an internship or community service. BYU-Idaho holds about a dozen community service events on campus each year.
Students are generally assigned a community ward for spiritual and social growth. Student ward meeting attendance is mandatory for enrollment.
name: Brigham Young University-Idaho

description:
Austin College is an intimate private liberal arts college in Sherman, TX, that provides hands-on opportunities that rival larger institutions.
The college offers more than 50 undergraduate areas of study. Popular programs include psychology, biology and business. All students take part in JanTerm, which offers in-depth study and research, as well as international opportunities.
The tight-knit community engages with each other through the more than 70 student organizations, which almost 80% of students take part in. The college’s 17 sororities and fraternities are unique to Austin and have no national affiliations.
Approximately 22% of students are first-generation, and over half of students identify as a racial or ethnic minority.
Every freshman receives gift aid from the college. Merit scholarships range from $18,000 to $31,000, and students can also apply to talent awards for fine arts. Austin’s Finish in Four guarantee waives tuition costs for any courses students need to complete their degree beyond four years.
Approximately 92% of graduates are employed or continuing education within one year.
name: Austin College

description:
Founded in 1858, Linfield College is a private liberal arts school in McMinnville, OR, that maintains loose ties to its founding Baptist Church.
The school officially changed its name from Linfield College to Linfield University last year.
Linfield has another campus in Portland, about an hour drive from the main campus.
About a quarter of Linfield students receive Pell grants, while 94% of all incoming undergraduates receive some form of aid.
Notable Linfield alumni include Amy Tan, author of The Joy Luck Club, and Scott Brosius, former World Series MVP.
name: Linfield University

description:
Founded by the Dominican Sisters of Sparkill in 1952, St. Thomas Aquinas College is a small liberal arts school located in Sparkill, NY, a small town about 60 minutes north of New York City.
St. Thomas Aquinas partners with several New York colleges for accelerated graduate programs, such as a partnership with New York University that allows St. Thomas Aquinas Psychology majors to obtain a Master of Social Work in five years total.
The Bloomberg Professional Laboratory opened in 2015 equipped with 12 Bloomberg terminals and a ticker tape sign and is open to students in the business or arts and sciences programs.
85% of students receive scholarships and grants as part of their financial aid package. The Aquinas Leaders Work Scholarship Program offers opportunities for work experience with a mentor.
Barbara Corcoran, venture capitalist and one of the “sharks” on Shark Tank, is a St. Thomas Aquinas alumna.
name: St. Thomas Aquinas College

description:
Pacific Lutheran University in Tacoma, WA is a private Lutheran university that encourages inquiry and civic engagement.
Students can choose from almost 40 majors. Popular programs include business administration, nursing and kinesiology.
PLU aims to cultivate a community that is globally and civically engaged—half of students study abroad, and over 70% of students volunteer.
All freshmen are considered for PLU Academic Scholarships, ranging from $5,000 to $25,000 annually. The university also has a number of full-tuition scholarships, including the Regents’ Scholarships and the 253 PLU Bound Scholarship for Washington high school students. The PLU Pledge helps repay loans if the student is making less than $50,000 annually.
Approximately 90% of students are employed or in graduate school within six months of graduating, and the university has produced over 100 Fulbright scholars since 1975.
name: Pacific Lutheran University

description:
Murray State University in Murray, KY is a public institution that places value on individualized attention in and outside of the classroom.
Murray State offers more than 60 undergraduate programs. Popular majors include animal health technology, agricultural science and nursing. The university also has five regional campuses and online degree programs.
About 40% of students complete internships or co-ops, and more than 1,000 students conduct research. Aside from academics, students take part in over 100 clubs, including Greek life. Residential colleges provide a tight-knit community within the larger university community.
Merit awards range from $1,000 to full tuition. MSU offers regional tuition discounts for residents of Illinois, Indiana, Missouri, Mississippi, Tennessee, Arkansas and Alabama.
The majority of alumni remain in Kentucky.
name: Murray State University

description:
Valparaiso University in Valparaiso, IN, is a private institution that emphasizes leadership and Lutheran values through its education.
Undergraduates can choose from over 70 majors. Popular programs include nursing, mechanical engineering and finance.
Students are busy outside of the classroom, from engaging in research—the university allocates $10,000 annually to fund undergraduate projects—to studying abroad, which 35% do. Valpo has centers in England, Germany, Costa Rica and China.
Valparaiso is located about an hour away from Chicago, IL, providing robust extracurricular opportunities for students. Students complete more than 247,000 hours of community service annually. On campus, there’s more than 100 clubs, Greek life and Division I sports.
Approximately 70% of respondents from the Class of 2020 are employed and 21% are continuing their education. Top industries for recent graduates include nursing, education and engineering.
name: Valparaiso University

description:
Originally founded in 1885 as a mining school, South Dakota School of Mines and Technology is the state’s modern leader in STEM education.
More than three-quarters of students are engineers.
South Dakota Mines’ campus is home to The Museum of Geology. Visitors to the museum can see mounted skeletons of dinosaurs, meteorites and rare fossils from the nearby White River Badlands.
Located in the Rushmore Region, campus is 25 miles from Mount Rushmore National Memorial.
Most South Dakota Mines alumni continue in engineering after graduation—the most popular employers of alumni are Kiewit, one of the largest American construction companies and Garmin, a worldwide leader in GPS technology.
organizationName: South Dakota School of Mines and Technology
name: South Dakota School of Mines and Technology

description:
The University of Alabama in Huntsville is a public space-grant university in northern Alabama.
NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center is located in Huntsville, and much of UAH’s research is done in conjunction with the government agency.
Fittingly, aerospace engineering is one of the most popular majors at UAH. More than a quarter of students major in engineering.
Huntsville’s climate may be warm and humid, but that doesn’t stop the school from hitting the ice. The UAH Chargers are one of only two Division I hockey teams in the Sun Belt.
Notable UAH alumni include NASA Outstanding Leadership Medal-winning astronaut Jan Davis and Discovery Communication founder John Hendricks.
name: University of Alabama in Huntsville

description:
About 27 miles northwest of Philadelphia in Collegeville, PA, Ursinus is a liberal arts college that encourages students to explore academic and professional opportunities.
The 170-acre campus is home to many amenities, including an art museum and a sustainable farm. The college has three centers for student development, which focus on global service-learning, science and society and entrepreneurial pursuits.
There are 34 majors for students to choose from, as well as five professional programs, 10 areas of specialization and 59 minors. Every first-year student must complete the “Common Intellectual Experience,” a two-semester course that fosters reading, writing and interpretive skills.
About 99% of students receive some form of financial aid. Every first year applicant is automatically considered for merit scholarships of up to $40,000.
Students take part in more than 100 clubs and organizations. Around 20% of students participate in the college’s eight sororities and five fraternities.
name: Ursinus College

description:
Located in the vibrant and historic city, the University of New Orleans is a public research institution with a wide range of offerings.
Undergraduates can choose from almost 40 majors. Popular courses of study include business, engineering and biology. UNO offers the only civil engineering, electrical engineering and mechanical engineering programs in the New Orleans area.
UNO is the only urban research center in Louisiana. The Tolmas Scholars program provides funding for undergraduates to work on research projects.
Students can take part in more than 125 clubs, Greek life and Division I sports. Campus is just 15 minutes from the French Quarter, allowing for students to easily take part in the world-renowned food, music and festivals the city offers.
More than half of alumni live and work in the greater New Orleans metropolitan area. About 90% of students are employed within two years of graduating.
name: University of New Orleans

description:
Le Moyne College is a private Jesuit institution spanning 160 acres in Syracuse, NY. The college is known for its pre-professional programs.
There are 80 majors at the college for students to choose from, many of which are specializations in business, health care and information technology.
Within one year of graduating, 98% of students found employment in their field or enrolled in graduate school.
About 95% of students receive some form of financial aid, with the average aid award for freshmen at around $25,000. The college offers merit scholarships that are valued up to $100,000, as well as a separate merit scholarship of up to $80,000 for first-year students who graduated from a Jesuit high school.
On the annual Dolphy Day at the end of the winter months, Le Moyne students have the day off from classes and celebrate spring in the warm weather.
name: Le Moyne College

description:
The University of Idaho in Moscow, ID, is a land-grant university with a research-driven and innovative culture.
Undergraduates can choose from over 90 degree programs, as well as pre-professional tracks in a number of health sciences fields. Popular majors include psychology, mechanical engineering and marketing. The university also offers programs at four other locations in Idaho, including Boise.
U of I has ​​over $113.1 million in research expenditures annually. Undergraduates are encouraged to take part in research, and about 75% do so.
Almost a quarter of the student body participates in Greek life. With more than 200 clubs and an Outdoor Program that offers rentals and trips, there is plenty to do outside of the classroom. The Idaho Vandals compete at the NCAA Division I level.
Idaho students are eligible for merit scholarships ranging from $1,000 to $4,000, and the Vandal Promise program provides additional scholarship and grant support that enables low-income Idaho residents attend.​​ U of I is part of the Western Undergraduate Exchange program, which allows students from select states to attend for reduced out-of-state tuition.
name: University of Idaho

description:
Maine Maritime Academy in Castine, ME, is a small public institution dedicated to producing officers and engineers for the U.S. Merchant Marine and other nautical leaders.
All of MMA’s academic programs center around engineering, management, science, and transportation. Majors include marine systems engineering and vessels operations and technology.
MMA students don’t need to venture far for amenities, as the Curtis Hall dormitory has its own barber shop, gaming lounge and computer lab.
The MMA learning experience is unique: learning facilities include research vessels, marine science labs, power plant and navigation simulators and a liquid cargo system simulator.
MMA ranks as one of the top schools in terms of time to recoup investment and 94% of students receive some form of financial assistance.
name: Maine Maritime Academy

description:
The University of Scranton provides a Jesuit liberal arts education that stresses the values of justice and service. The 58-acre campus is located in downtown Scranton, PA, two hours from Philadelphia and New York City.
The university offers 68 majors and ten concentration programs. The most popular programs are in health care fields, such as nursing and kinesiology.
The university partners with local community organizations for students to participate in service. Students perform more than 170,000 hours of volunteer work every year.
About 96% of students are offered university scholarships or need-based aid. Students are automatically considered for several merit scholarships.
There are about 80 clubs on campus for students to join, including honor societies, spiritual groups and nonprofit organizations.
name: University of Scranton

description:
A highly specialized school in Atherton, CA, Menlo College is a small private institution that focuses on matching the entrepreneurial spirit of its Silicon Valley home.
Menlo’s academics are geared toward preparing students for a career in business, as nearly all of its academic programs are business-related, the only exception being its psychology major.
More than half of Menlo students identify as non-white and 17% of the student body hails from a foreign country.
Internships are required for business majors and an Internship Seminar course reflecting on the experience is a graduation requirement.
Notable Menlo alumni include billionaire businessman John Pritzker and Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal Al Saud.
name: Menlo College

description:
Located outside of Atlanta, GA, Agnes Scott College is an innovative women’s college with an experiential learning-based liberal arts core.
The college offers close to 40 undergraduate majors, as well as programs in pre-health and pre-law. Psychology, biology and neuroscience are among the popular programs. Agnes Scott is part of the Atlanta Regional Council for Higher Education institution, allowing students to cross-register at any of the 18 other member colleges.
Students take advantage of hands-on experiences at Agnes Scott; all first-year students engage in global immersion as part of the lliberal arts curriculum, and about half study abroad again. On average, 70% of students complete an internship and 36% are involved in research.
The tight-knit community comes together through its 60 student organizations and wealth of traditions, including the sophomore ring ceremony. More than 80% of students are involved in community service.
As a women’s college, Agnes Scott admits students who were assigned female at birth, as well as those who were assigned male or female at birth but who now identify as female, transgender, agender, gender fluid or non-binary.
New for Fall 2022, all incoming students will receive the Agnes Assurance Scholarship, worth $22,000 annually, or a merit scholarship in a higher amount up to $26,000 annually. The college also offers awards covering the cost of attendance through Presidential Scholarships, and for Hispanic students through the Goizueta Scholarship.
name: Agnes Scott College

description:
Known for its commitment to research and its historic Scottish ties, the College of Wooster is a small private liberal arts school in Wooster, OH.
All Wooster undergraduates participate in research, matching one-on-one with a faculty member for an Independent Study capstone project in their senior year.
Wooster’s 21 Division III varsity sports teams compete as the Fighting Scots, an allusion to the school’s roots in the Presbyterian Church.
The school’s Scottish affinity goes further than athletics: the Wooster Scottish Arts Society fields a Pipe Band and Highland Dancers, and offers “Scottish Arts” scholarships on an audition basis.
Some 97% of Wooster graduates report gaining admission to their top-choice graduate school.
name: College of Wooster

description:
Calvin University is a private liberal arts school in Grand Rapids, MI, that is affiliated with the Christian Reformed Church. The university implements faith-based teachings into education and professional development.
Students are required to take two courses in foundations of Christianity. There are more than 100 majors and programs for students to choose from, the most popular being engineering, nursing and business.
There are more than 70 student-led organizations on campus, including several academic clubs for engineers and faith and service organizations. There is no Greek life at Calvin.
The university holds chapel service every day, and all students are invited to attend. About 28% of students at Calvin identify as Christian Reformed.
Nearly all students receive some form of financial aid. The university offers several legacy and diversity scholarships, such as a $5,000 scholarship for children of alumni or Christian Reformed parents.
name: Calvin University

description:
Hampden-Sydney College in Hampden Sydney, VA, is one of the few remaining men’s colleges in the country. The private liberal arts college prides itself on providing a collaborative learning environment and sense of brotherhood.
The college offers 27 majors for students to choose from. Students are required to complete the Rhetoric Program, a rigorous public speaking and analytical writing course sequence.
There are more than 60 clubs on campus, including some dozen academic groups and 10 fraternities. Many students participate in a variety of outdoor activities on Hampden-Sydney’s 1,300-acre campus near the Blue Ridge Mountains.
All applicants are automatically considered for merit scholarships of up to $30,000. There is also a $20,000 per year scholarship for students who are eagle scouts, who make up about 10% of the student body.
name: Hampden-Sydney College

description:
Located blocks from Lake Michigan, the University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee is a large, vibrant community that places emphasis on experiential learning.
Students can choose from over 200 academic programs, including pre-professional tracks and online degrees. UWM has other locations, including two campuses in Waukesha and Washington County.
Half of undergraduates participate in research and enjoy the benefits of working at an institution that is distinguished as R1—the highest Carnegie classification. UWM boasts more than 20 research centers and over 100 patents created. The Innovation Campus houses an accelerator for researchers and business leaders to meet.
The university offers almost 300 clubs, Division I athletics and Greek life. Students also take advantage of the vibrant city, where 1,400 employers host UWM interns and students take part in almost 40,000 hours of volunteering.
Incoming freshmen are automatically considered for scholarships ranging from $500 to $1,500 annually.
name: University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee

description:
A large public university in Ellensburg, WA, Central Washington University is committed to hands-on learning and personal development.
Central Washington offers its students over 130 majors to choose from, including notable programs in geology, music, paramedicine and physics.
Students stay active: Central Washington houses more than 125 student groups, including 23 club sports, but no Greek life. The Central Washington Wildcats play in 13 NCAA D2 sports.
The average out-of-pocket cost after scholarships and aid is about $3,000. Washington State high school graduates with high GPAs are eligible for the Presidential Scholarship.
Notable alumni include former Secretary of Defense James Mattis and former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ron Sims.
name: Central Washington University

description:
Originally founded as an agricultural and mechanical college, Mississippi State University is a land-grant university in Starkville, MS, that has upheld its tradition of being a leader in agriculture and natural resource research.
MSU offers more than 175 different programs at the undergraduate and graduate level in the university’s eight academic colleges.
The land, sea and space grant institution has the highest Carnegie research classification and has been a National Science Foundation top 100 research university for nearly two decades. For the 2019 fiscal year, the university had more than $264.5 million in research and development expenditures, an increase of $20 million from the previous year.
At 4,200 acres, the MSU campus is one of the largest in the country. A sense of campus pride is cultivated through Division I athletics — including the Cowbell Yell pep rally — more than 300 student organizations and Greek life.
The Ole Miss Opportunity Program guarantees that Mississippi residents with a family adjusted gross income below $32,5000 will receive financial aid to cover the cost of tuition, residence hall housing and meals.
name: Mississippi State University

description:
Hope College is a small private liberal arts school affiliated with the Reformed Church in America in Holland, MI. vHope is piloting a pay-it-forward tuition model this fall, with 22 students receiving free tuition thanks to a gift from a private donor. The program, called “Hope Forward,” aims to eventually provide free tuition to all students through alumni gifts.
Through “Day 1 Research Communities”, freshmen at Hope can participate in lab or field research as soon as classes start.
Hope offers more than 90 majors, spanning from Accounting to Ministry.
