The Hope College Book Club connects the larger Hope community. The club reads a book every two months and is open to alumni, current students, staff, faculty and families.
name: Hope College

description:
Wittenberg University in Springfield, OH is a Lutheran-affiliated college that has strengths in both the liberal arts and pre-professional programs.
Undergraduates can choose from over 30 majors and more than 10 pre-professional programs in engineering and the health sciences. Students can also partake in cooperative programs with other colleges and universities, including Columbia University and Duke University. Popular majors include biology, early childhood education and marketing.
Students engage in more than 25,000 hours of community service annually. There are over 100 clubs, and about one-third of students take part in Greek life. First year students are encouraged to participate in research, and funding opportunities are available to assist faculty members with their projects.
Merit scholarships range from $17,000 to $27,000, and high school valedictorians and salutatorians qualify for a $30,000 annual award. Wittenberg also offers a number of application-based awards for academic and extracurricular interests.
Approximately 92% of the class of 2020 is employed or in graduate school.
name: Wittenberg University

description:
Christopher Newport University in Newport News, VA, is a public university that encourages hands-on experiences and a comprehensive liberal arts education.
Students can choose from over 40 undergraduate majors, with popular programs in business, biology and psychology. CNU prides itself on its robust core curriculum, which requires the study of literature, composition, economics, mathematics, a foreign language, science and American history.
Undergraduate research is a cornerstone of the CNU experience. The university provides funding for the mentored learning projects and summer research programs.
There are more than 200 student organizations on campus, including Greek life. The community is tight-knit, as students are required to live on campus for their first three years.
The President’s Leadership Program enrolls approximately 400 freshmen annually and integrates academic study, experiential learning and personal development. Students in the program receive a minimum $500 scholarship and funding for study abroad.
name: Christopher Newport University

description:
The Maryland Institute College of Art in Baltimore, MD, is the oldest continuously degree-granting college of art and design in the country.
Undergraduates can choose from 20 majors, including a five-year master of art education program. All students take core First Year Experience, a trans-disciplinary curriculum of inter-related courses addressing contemporary art and design practice. Students can also choose a studio concentration or a liberal arts minor.
Facilities include 10 makerspaces and studios, including the Make Cool Stuff Lab, a makerspace with 3D printers, digital cutters and other technology geared for freshmen to accustom them to the fundamentals of digital fabrication.
MICA has study abroad programs for fine art, design and media and humanistic studies, as well as summer travel intensives to London, Paris, South Korea, Venice, Sorrento and South Africa. Students take part in art-centric service projects in the Baltimore community and are part of special interest student organizations.
Annually, the college administers more than $60 million in financial assistance to undergraduate students, and the MICA-funded scholarships and grant programs provide more than $31 million.
name: Maryland Institute College of Art

description:
Stetson University is a private school whose main campus is in DeLand, FL, located halfway between Daytona Beach and Orlando.
Through the Roland George Investment Program, Stetson business students manage a real $5.5 million portfolio of bonds and stocks. More than a quarter of students major in a business field.
The Stetson Hatters field 18 Division I varsity teams, with all sports competing in the ASUN Conference, except for football, which is a member of the Pioneer Football League.
Some of Stetson’s most famous alumni played for the Hatters' baseball team: Cy Young Award winners Jacob deGrom and Corey Kluber both are Stetson alumni.
name: Stetson University

description:
Located about 18 miles away from Los Angeles in La Mirada, CA, Biola University offers a Christian education focused on spiritual growth and professional development.
There are 64 majors for students to choose from across Biola’s nine undergraduate schools and colleges. Every student is required to take foundational courses in theology and the Bible.
The university has merit scholarships ranging up to $20,000 a year for freshmen and transfer students. About 90% of undergraduates receive financial aid, which covers 52% of demonstrated need on average.
Biola is home to many student traditions, such as “Mock Rock,” where groups of students lip-sync songs in front of screaming fans, and floor events where roommates find each other a date.
In 2017, 70% of students completed at least one internship before graduating, and 90% of students reported finding employment or enrolling in graduate school within six months after graduation.
name: Biola University

description:
Founded in 1927 by evangelist Bob Jones, Bob Jones University is a Christian liberal arts school in Greenville, SC.
BJU is orthodox and historic fundamentalist in its Christian views, and this dictates a great deal of campus life. Abstinence from alcohol, inappropriate music, belief in monogamous heterosexual relationships and Creationism are all tenets of BJU.
There are majors across religious and secular fields, ranging from biblical counseling and ministry to accounting and nursing.
Scholarships are available for academic excellence for up to $10,000 annually, students whose parents are employed full-time in a Christian ministry as well as needs-based awards.
Residence halls are segregated by gender and each feature a prayer room, study lounge and vending room.
BJU is the alma mater of Arkansas governor Asa Hutchinson and evangelist Billy Kim.
name: Bob Jones University

description:
The artsiest member of the State University of New York system, SUNY at Purchase College is 30 miles north of New York City in Purchase, NY.
There are 47 majors at Purchase, many of which center around the arts, such as Acting, Studio Production and Voice and Opera Studies.
Purchase’s 500-acre campus almost exclusively features buildings of the same shade of light brick, metaphorically meant to emphasize that Purchase’s color comes from within.
More than 40% of students major in the visual and performing arts.
Purchase is a breeding ground for the biggest names in Hollywood, as actors Edie Falco, Wesley Snipes and Stanley Tucci are all alumni of the school.
name: SUNY at Purchase College

description:
The University of West Florida in Pensacola, FL is a public university that has a large in-state student population and is a major driver of economic impact in Northwest Florida.
UWF offers over 60 undergraduate majors across five colleges and online. Popular programs are in the health professions, business and computer and information sciences. The university’s other location, UWF Emerald Coast, offers curriculums for traditional and non-traditional students who have earned 60 or more semester hours.
UWF grants more than 150 travel awards annually to present research at national conferences, and students are eligible to request up to $500 to assist with research materials.
Minutes away from the beach, the 1,600-acre campus is home to twenty-five miles of hiking and biking nature trails, as well as 150 student organizations.
Scholarships range up to full tuition, including the National Merit Finalist Scholarship and the Argo Spirit Scholarship for Pell Grant-eligible, first-time Florida residents.
name: University of West Florida

description:
Portland State University is a large public research university in the Oregon city’s downtown.
Portland State encourages eco-friendly forms of transportation, and bikes can be rented for $45 per semester.
Nearly 80% of students hail from Oregon, and in-state residents enjoy a $19,000 tuition discount compared to their out-of-state peers.
Portland State offers a free food market with fresh produce and other healthy options to address food insecurity on campus. The market has served more than 350,000 pounds of food to 13,000 Portland State students.
Notable Portland State alumni include D. Scott Davis, former UPS CEO, Carolyn Davidson, creator of the Nike swoosh logo, and Barbara Roberts, former Oregon governor.
name: Portland State University

description:
A midsize public university in Greeley, CO, the University of Northern Colorado known for educating and training teachers.
While UNC was established as a teaching college and is the home of the Education Innovation Institute, undergraduates can choose from dozens of majors, which include the liberal arts and pre-professional programs.
Students at UNC have plenty to do on campus, from intramural sports and sketch comedy to professional interest groups. There are 23 active fraternities and sororities on campus.
1,200 students study at the College of Performing and Visual Arts, which hosts more than 400 events a year for UNC’s students and the local community.
Notable UNC alumni include playwright Steven Dietz, Pulitzer Prize-winner James Michener and science fiction author Connie Willis.
name: University of Northern Colorado

description:
Founded as the first co-educational college south of the Mason-Dixon line, McDaniel College in Westminster, MD, is a private liberal arts school with a tight-knit community.
Students can choose from over 30 majors, and popular programs include business administration, kinesiology and communication. With a satellite location in Budapest, McDaniel students can take their studies internationally.
McDaniel emphasizes close student and faculty relations through the McDaniel Commitment, which provides students with mentors, and intimate class sizes. The college has funding opportunities through the Summer Intern Fellowships to encourage students to complete internships and research.
McDaniel’s mascot, Green Terror, not only cheers on McDaniel’s Division III sports teams, but represents the vibrant nature of campus, which is home to 85% of undergraduates and more than 70 student organizations.
Students are automatically considered for McDaniel Merit Scholarships, which range from $15,000 per year to $28,000 annually. The Dorsey Scholars Program is the most prestigious scholarship competition at McDaniel College and covers the cost of attendance.
name: McDaniel College

description:
Ohio Wesleyan University is a private liberal arts college in Delaware, OH, that prides itself on its intimate and lively community, bolstered by hands-on learning. Undergraduates can choose from over 70 majors, including 3-2 programs in biomedical engineering, computer science and physics. Popular programs include psychology, business administration and zoology. About one-third of students have more than one major.
Learning outside of the classroom is important at OWU. The curriculum allows every student to travel through travel-learning courses, conduct research through a 10-week summer program and complete internships. OWU has a program in Washington, D.C. where students can take classes and intern.
The community may be small, but it is vibrant. Students can take part in nearly 100 clubs and Greek life. Three-quarters of students take part in recreational, club or varsity sports, and students put in 45,000 of community service annually.
More than nine out of 10 graduates are employed or in graduate school.
name: Ohio Wesleyan University

description:
The University of Memphis is a large public research university in Tennessee’s second-largest city.
Campus is a 15-minute drive from Downtown Memphis and a mile from the Memphis Botanic Garden.
Memphis was awarded $50.2 million in research funding last year, marking a record for the school and a 23.2% increase from the year prior.
FedEx is headquartered near campus in Memphis, and the company sponsors the university’s FedEx Institute of Technology, Memphis’ hub for emerging technology research.
Some of Memphis’ most famous alumni once suited up for the school’s athletic teams, including Pro Football Hall of Famer Isaac Bruce and former NBA MVP Derrick Rose.
name: University of Memphis

description:
A STEM-focused state school, Montana Technological University is in the former heavyweight mining town of Butte, MT.
Montana Tech offers nearly 40 majors, including business and nursing options, but a majority of students (59%) major in engineering.
The Montana Tech student body takes advantage of the great outdoors, with options for fly-fishing, skiing, hunting, hiking and mountain biking all within a short drive of campus.
There are four research centers at Montana Tech. Three of the institutes are centered on mining and natural resources, while the fourth is focused on high-speed computing.
Three months after graduation, an average 70% of alumni reported their careers as “very related” to their area of study, with more than half (some 56%) employed in the state.
organizationName: Montana Tech of the University of Montana
name: Montana Tech of the University of Montana

description:
Point Loma Nazarene University is a liberal arts college in San Diego, CA, affiliated with the Church of the Nazarene. The university believes in helping students reach their potential through spiritual growth, academic achievement and service.
PLNU offers more than 60 undergraduate programs for students to pursue. Nursing, family sciences and business administration are among the most popular majors.
About 91% of students received some form of financial aid. In the 2019-20 academic year, around 62% of incoming students received a merit scholarship. Students may earn a merit scholarship without submitting test scores.
More than three-quarters of incoming freshmen join Alpha Groups, small faith and socializing organizations. PLNU holds men’s and women’s spiritual retreats away from the university several times a year.
The university offers students the opportunity to serve in several Christian ministries in San Diego. There are also 11 NCAA Division II sports teams and 14 different club sports on campus.
name: Point Loma Nazarene University

description:
Southern Illinois University-Carbondale is the flagship institution in the public Southern Illinois system.
SIU was founded in 1869 as a teacher’s college and the school’s roots still stand, with 10% of students majoring in education.
The area surrounding SIU campus is bucolic, with two state parks and four recreational lakes within 10 miles of campus.
Home to 23 research centers and institutes, SIU received $69 million in external research funding last year.
SIU has recently recognized a pair of noteworthy alumni in the performing arts, as actress Melissa McCarthy and actor Bob Odenkirk both received honorary doctorates from the university since 2019.
name: Southern Illinois University Carbondale

description:
North Dakota State University is a land-grant research university in Fargo, with a wide range of specializations, including agricultural sciences, business, communications, STEM and performing arts.
Undergraduates choose from 100 majors. Popular programs include nursing, mechanical engineering and pharmacy. As part of the Tri-College University partnership, students can take classes at one of the member schools, including Concordia College in Minnesota, at no additional cost.
NDSU has more than 270 student organizations and Division I sports. Over 700 students take part in Greek life.
In addition to other forms of financial aid, NDSU awards nearly $3.5 million in scholarships to freshmen annually. Almost half of freshmen in 2021 received an award. Guaranteed scholarships range from $1,500 to $3,000 annually, and the Cultural Diversity Tuition Waiver awards up to full tuition for students from underrepresented backgrounds.
Approximately 88% of the Class of 2020 is either employed or in graduate school.
name: North Dakota State University

description:
Located in Galloway Township, NJ, Stockton University is a public university spanning 1,600 acres in the Pinelands National Reserve.
Stockton University has 116 undergraduate areas of study across its seven schools. Health services is the most popular program, followed by business, psychology and criminology.
The university prides itself on the Stockton University Foundation, a merit scholarship program with around 200 scholarships. The Stockton Promise covers the gap between aid and the cost of tuition and fees for full-time in-state students who have a gross income below $65,000 and a family contribution of $15,000 or less.
About 13% of undergraduates are members of 28 fraternity and sorority chapters at the school. The Stockton Ospreys compete in 17 varsity NCAA Division III teams.
name: Stockton University

description:
Berea College, located in Berea, KY, guarantees that no student at the college has to pay tuition through awarding a Tuition Promise Scholarship valued at almost $200,000 over four years.
Students at Berea are expected to participate in the work program at the college, where they work at least 10 hours per week throughout each regular term.
Out of 44 undergraduate fields of study, including the popular biology, computer science and industrial production technologies, there is an option to create a custom major.
About 93% of the class of 2019 graduates had studied abroad, fulfilled a paid internship, completed a service-learning course or participated in faculty-led research by the time they graduated.
Berea College has a number of performing arts clubs, including music and theatre groups. There are also several campus publications and many multicultural organizations.
name: Berea College

description:
Central Michigan University in Mount Pleasant, MI, is a public research university with a large student body and a wide range of academic offerings.
CMU offers more than 200 undergraduate programs, as well as accelerated and online programs. In addition to its main campus, the university has satellite locations across Michigan, the U.S. and in Canada. Exercise science, business and communications are popular programs.
The university operates an island biological research station on Beaver Island, where students can lodge while they conduct research.
Students can take part in over 400 student organizations, including Greek life and Division I sports.
Merit awards cover from 20% to 65% of tuition for up to four years. Competitive awards include the Centralis Scholarship Program, which covers up to the cost of attendance. Over $300 million is awarded in scholarships and financial aid annually.
name: Central Michigan University

description:
The University of Nebraska, Omaha is a public research institution that is committed to its role as a metropolitan university by prioritizing community service and engagement.
UNO offers over 100 majors, with specializations in STEM, child welfare and sustainability. The university has two other campuses and offers online degrees.
UNO receives millions of research dollars—almost three-quarters of its funding—from agencies including the U.S. Department of Defense, National Science Foundation, National Institutes of Health and NASA.
In 2020, more than 5,000 students put in over 300,000 hours of community service.
Over 30% of students are first-generation. The Nebraska Promise covers tuition costs for Nebraska residents who are Pell grant recipients or have a family income of $60,000 or less. Merit scholarships range up to full tuition.
name: University of Nebraska, Omaha

description:
Established in 2013, the University of Texas, Rio Grande Valley, the newest of the University of Texas System institutions, is the result of a combination of UT Brownsville and UT-Pan American.
UTRGV offers more than 120 undergraduate and graduate programs across 13 colleges and schools. The most popular undergraduate programs include health professions, education, engineering.
UTRGV has a campus in Edinburg, TX, about an hour away from the main campus in Brownsville, TX. Annual events include the Best Week Ever, a week-long celebration to kick off the academic year, and Charreada, which celebrates Brownsville’s Mexican heritage.
The Texas–Rio Grande Valley Vaqueros compete in the NCAA’s Division I, but students can also take part in sports clubs like flag football, softball, chess and soccer.
About 3% of the student body comes from another country, with the most coming from Mexico, India and China. Close to 80% of the student body identifies as Hispanic.
organizationName: University of Texas, Rio Grande Valley
name: University of Texas, Rio Grande Valley

description:
Since its inception as a teachers college, the University of Northern Iowa in Cedar Falls, IA, has emphasized hands-on service learning.
Undergraduates can choose from over 90 majors across four colleges. Popular programs include elementary education, psychology and business administration.
UNI funds hundreds of hours of research conducted by undergraduates during the academic year and over the summer. As part of the National Student Exchange, students can take their talents to a partner university while paying UNI tuition. Top destinations include the University of South Carolina, New Mexico State University and the University of Montana.
Scholarships with automatic consideration range up to $14,000 for in-state students and $20,000 for out-of-state students. The Bright Scholars of Iowa awards provides the cost of attendance to a Pell Grant-eligible Iowa student with high academic achievements.
Six months following graduation, approximately 80% of the Class of 2020 was employed and 13% was continuing their education. Historically, the majority—about 75%—of students remain in Iowa post-graduation.
name: University of Northern Iowa

description:
For over 130 years, Cedarville University in Cedarville, OH has integrated higher education with discipleship.
Students can choose from more than 150 programs of study at Cedarville. Popular programs are in the health professions, business, engineering and education. All students have a Bible minor, and biblical integration is built into every course.
Faith is a hallmark of campus life. Every weekday morning, students, faculty, and staff come together for a required chapel service, and students are expected to abstain from pre-marital sex and homosexuality.
Approximately 80% of undergraduates live on campus.
Academic scholarships range from $10,000 up to $20,000 per year and are renewable for all four years. All freshmen receive scholarships, with the average award being $17,950.
Approximately 96% of Cedarville’s 2020 graduates were employed or attending graduate school six to eight months after graduation.
name: Cedarville University

description:
Augustana College in Rock Island, IL, is a liberal arts college that focuses on mentorship with advisors and exploration through professional opportunities.
The college offers around 80 majors and pre-professional programs. Biology is by far the most populous major. Topics in business and psychology are also popular programs.
Students have the opportunity to pursue research across any discipline in the field, a classroom, or a lab. Students are also encouraged to study abroad or complete an internship. Each year, the college gives the Augie Choice, a $2,000 fund, to around 550 students to complete one of these opportunities.
For the class of 2019, 98% of graduates reported being employed or enrolled in graduate school within six months of commencement.
There are around 200 clubs at the college for students to take part in, including 15 Greek life organizations.
name: Augustana College

description:
Juniata is a private liberal arts college in Huntingdon, PA, with a 110-acre main campus and two 365-acre nature preserves.
Instead of choosing a major, students work with advisers to determine a program of emphasis, of which there are around 100. Biology is the most popular program by far. Almost 30% of students design their own program.
About 80% of students have at least one internship by the time they graduate, and almost half of students study abroad.
Juniata has many unique traditions, such as “Mountain Day,” when students skip class for a day of activities at a state park. The school hosts a Maine lobster picnic (“Lobsterfest”) after the first week of fall classes.
On average, the college meets 93% of students’ demonstrated financial need. For gamers, Juniata offers an esports scholarship of up to $2,500.
name: Juniata College

description:
The only Edmundite college in the world, Saint Michael’s College in Colchester, VT, is a private liberal arts college that emphasizes experiential learning.
Students can choose from over 40 majors, as well as dual degree programs with other colleges, like Clarkson University and the University of Vermont. Popular programs include business administration, psychology and biology.
In line with its Catholic roots, approximately 70% of students volunteer during their education. Additionally, more than a third of students study abroad.
About 90% of students receive financial aid and all students are considered for merit awards, including the “Purple & Gold” Scholarships, which range from $17,000 to $30,000 annually. Nomination is required for the Book Award and the Presidential Scholarship, the latter of which is for Vermont students.
Saint Michael’s has a 95% placement rate for full-time employment or graduate school. About 5% of alumni partake in full-time service programs.
name: Saint Michael's College

description:
SUNY College at Old Westbury is a mid-sized public university on a 604-acre suburban Long Island, 22 miles from New York City.
The Old Westbury community is extremely diverse, as 33% of students identify as Hispanic, 26% as White, 25% as Black, 11% as Asian and 5% international students and other backgrounds.
Psychology is the most popular academic program, with 15% of students majoring in the subject and an active chapter of the Psi Chi international honor society in psychology.
The college is primarily a commuter school, though about 800 students live on campus.
Old Westbury alumni can stay very closely connected to their alma mater: they can audit one class per semester for free.
name: SUNY College at Old Westbury

description:
Westminster College is a private college in Salt Lake City, UT, that provides a blend of liberal arts and pre-professional experiences.
The college offers over 30 undergraduate majors, and popular programs include nursing, finance and marketing.
Students have logged hundreds of thousands of community engagement work through the Katherine W. Dumke Center for Civic Engagement, which facilitates volunteer opportunities and community-engaged learning.
There is plenty to do on campus with more than 40 student organizations. Off campus, students take advantage of the nature in Utah, including the 10 ski resorts within an hour drive of the college. Half of the students hail from Utah.
All incoming students in the 2020–21 academic year received a grant or scholarship. Merit awards range from $11,000 to $27,000. The college also awards talent scholarships for theater, music, athletics, computer science and dance.
name: Westminster College (UT)

description:
Lewis University is a Catholic and Lasallian school in suburban Chicago.
Aviation education has been a crucial part of Lewis’ identity since its founding, and the university has partnerships with O’Hare and Midway International airports.
Lewis’ 410-acre main Romeoville campus is 35 miles southwest of Chicago and the school also operates three satellite campuses.
The core curriculum spans six disciplines, including professional skills and Catholic and Lasallian tradition.
Lewis offers a variety of five-year accelerated bachelor’s and master’s programs, like the B.S. to M.S. in Aviation and Transportation and the B.S. to M.S. in Business Analytics.
name: Lewis University

description:
A mid-sized public school, Radford University is located in rural southwestern Virginia.
Radford was an all women’s school for its first six decades of existence, and that heritage follows it to this day with a student body that is 61% female.
Radford has six colleges, but all students must complete the same four-course interdisciplinary core curriculum. It follows that the most popular field is multi/interdisciplinary studies.
The university also offers a clinical-based health sciences educational experience in Roanoke, VA, as part of Radford University Carilion, a partnership with Carilion Medical Center.
Named for the Scots-Irish heritage of southwest Virginia, the Radford Highlanders field 16 varsity teams that compete in the Division I Big South Conference.
name: Radford University

description:
A midsize, private university in New York City, Touro offers a wide range of liberal arts and professional programs grounded in Orthodox Jewish values and traditions.
True to its Orthodox roots, undergraduates at Touro’s Lander College of Arts and Sciences are divided into separate men’s and women’s programs. Both programs offer 20 majors, including professional programs in IT, education and business management. All students must complete 48 credits of Judaic study to graduate.
Students can study in Israeli yeshivas through the Touro College in Israel Program. Credits earned in Israel can be applied to a Touro degree in the US.
Men and women maintain separate housing at Touro. Men can apply to live in one of 13 attached townhouses, while women can apply to live in suites on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
name: Touro College

description:
Founded as a Catholic school for women in 1955, Molloy College today is a co-educational school in Rockville Centre, NY, known for its nursing programs.
Molloy is primarily a commuter school, though it does have three residence halls housing 300-plus students.
All first-year students belong to a freshman learning community, including topics such as “Law and Order” and “Keeping America Healthy.”
The 550-seat Madison Theatre on campus hosts dance, musical and theatrical performances.
Nearly half of undergraduates major in nursing. Molloy nursing education is centered around a humanistic approach and students hone their skills in Molloy’s skills and simulation learning laboratory.
name: Molloy College

description:
Dating back to 1991, Florida Gulf Coast is a large public university in Fort Myers, FL, and the second youngest member of the State University of Florida system.
FGCU has kept tuition flat for seven years. 73% of students receive some form of financial aid, including $30 million in scholarships every year, and 52% of graduates leave with no debt.
Undergraduates at FGCU can choose from 63 majors, with pre-professional programs in digital media design, legal studies and music therapy.
The school’s 800 acre campus includes 350 acres of preserved Florida wetlands and a 15-acre solar energy field. The “Wings of Hope” program partners the school with local elementary school students to teach them about Florida’s natural ecosystems.
82% of the class of 2019 was employed a year after graduating.
name: Florida Gulf Coast University

description:
Berry College is a private liberal arts college in Rome, GA, that plants the seeds for students’ careers.
Berry offers over 75 areas of study across four schools, as well as pre-professional programs and a dual-degree engineering program with the Georgia Institute of Technology or Kennesaw State University.
The college has a unique pride point — at 27,000 acres, it is the world’s largest campus. With this size, there is a wealth of opportunities, including over 1,000 jobs on campus through Berry’s unique LifeWorks program, which provides students with eight semesters of paid professional experience.
The college cultivates a tight-knit community, with every freshman being assigned with peer and faculty mentors. Berry has a number of scholar programs for Hispanic and Latinx students and those dedicated to service. Outside of the classroom, students can take part in some of the 75 student organizations.
Approximately 98% of students are employed or in graduate school within six months of graduating.
name: Berry College

description:
One of six senior military colleges in the nation, Norwich University has a famous school motto of ​​”I will try.”
Founded in 1819 in Norwich, VT, Norwich is the birthplace of ROTC. Today, two-thirds of residential students join the school’s Corps of Cadets. Twenty-five percent of students are female.
Norwich’s unique Studies In War and Peace (SWAP) major takes an interdisciplinary approach to analyzing conflicts. SWAP majors take classes in history, political science, economics, philosophy and more.
Norwich has Army, Navy and Air Force ROTC programs, organized in the College of National Service.
The aptly named Norwich Cadets field 20 varsity athletic teams. The Cadets are very successful in Division III, claiming 12 national championships.
name: Norwich University

description:
Susquehanna University in Selinsgrove, PA, is a private liberal arts school that encourages students to engage in experiential learning.
SU offers more than 100 majors and minors across four schools. Popular programs include communication studies, marketing and psychology.
The university emphasizes learning outside of the classroom. SU requires all students to study off campus, and 95% choose to do so abroad. The SU Service Leaders program is a four-year internship program in which students work with community partners who focus on youth development.
There are more than 150 student organizations, including Greek life, to engage with. Off campus, students take advantage of the wealth of state parks within two hours of the university. Students can also rent a bike from Outdoor Recreation, which also sponsors outdoor adventure trips.
Merit awards range up to $38,000 annually.
name: Susquehanna University

description:
The Massachusetts Maritime Academy is a public college in Buzzards Bay, MA, originally established in 1891 to graduate Merchant Marine deck and engineering officers.
The academy offers undergraduate programs in engineering, marine science, emergency management and transportation and business. Marine engineering is the most popular program.
Many cadets are required to complete four “Sea Terms,” six-week voyages where cadets gain hands-on experience on the USTS Kennedy.
About 10% of graduates from MMA pursue military service.
There are a variety of clubs that cadets can join, including the Seventh Company regimental band, honor guard and drill team. Many freshmen compete in intramural sports for the Commandant’s Cup to build camaraderie within their company
name: Massachusetts Maritime Academy

description:
One of two public honors colleges in the country, St. Mary's College of Maryland is a small school 75 miles southeast of Washington, D.C.
St. Mary’s academics are guided by the “Learning Through Experiential and Applied Discovery” (LEAD) principle. LEAD entails a core curriculum, study of a foreign language and a capstone project.
Campus is home to a 100-seat movie theater, fire pits, a climbing wall and a 50-meter swimming pool.
The St Mary’s River is immediately to the west of campus, and students can enjoy waterfront views from their dorm rooms and free access to kayaks, paddleboards and windsurfing equipment.
Nearly 40% of the Class of 2020 studied abroad.
name: St. Mary's College of Maryland

description:
With an 85-acre campus in the heart of downtown Cleveland, OH, Cleveland State University is a robust and rapidly changing public institution.
In March the school unveiled the CSU 2.0 initiative, aiming to bring on 4,500 new students and 200 additional faculty members by 2025 and invest millions in research and new programs and partnerships.
In addition to some 200 fields of study, CSU is allied with about 250 partners, including the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, NASA Glenn Research Center, for additional learning and work experiences.
This fall this school is offering a 2-1 tuition program: First time freshmen who complete Fall 2021 with a 3.0 GPA or better will not need to pay tuition for Spring 2022. In 2018, CSU established the School of Film & Media Arts, the first standalone film school in Ohio. The school features multiple sound stages, studios and views of Lake Erie.
There are more than 120,000 members of the CSU alumni network, of which 80% reside in the greater Cleveland area.
name: Cleveland State University

description:
Texas Woman’s University, located in Denton, TX, is one of the country’s largest universities primarily for women.
Undergraduates can choose from 100 programs, and business and the health professions are the most popular areas of study. The university also has locations in Dallas and Houston.
TWU has 10 institutes and centers and is an affiliate of the Texas Space Grant Consortium, which advances space research and technology. Students enjoy the academic and extracurricular benefits of being under an hour away from Dallas.
The university is a Hispanic-Serving Institution, and more than half of students are from a diverse background.
About 84% of alumni are working or continuing their education within a year of graduating.
name: Texas Woman's University

description:
A California State University system member 275 miles north of San Francisco, Humboldt State University is set to undergo a major transformation.
In August, the California state legislature announced a $458 million investment to transform Humboldt State into the first polytechnic institution in northern California. The investment will go into areas such as new academic buildings, residence halls and renewable energy research.
Humboldt State offers three green majors—Environmental Resources Engineering, Environmental Science & Management and Environmental Studies.
Campus is in close proximity to California’s ancient redwood forests and Pacific coastline.
SpongeBob SquarePants creator Stephen Hillenburg is an alumnus and a gift from him established the Stephen Hillenburg Marine Science Research Award Endowment in 2017.
name: Humboldt State University

description:
Named after a Benedectine monk, Saint Anselm College is a Catholic liberal arts school in Manchester, NH.
The college is a popular destination for presidential debates, most recently the Democratic Party’s presidential primary debate in Feb. 2020.
The Cyber Criminology major was added for the 2020-21 academic year, bolstering Saint Anselm’s already popular criminology program. Other popular programs include nursing, business and finance.
The community’s celebration of its patron saint’s feast day continued through the pandemic with a live-streamed solemn mass plus a virtual trivia night and “Beers and Benedictines” event.
Saint Anselm campus is also home to an abbey, with 30 Benedictine monks called the monastery home.
name: Saint Anselm College

description:
Founded in 1854 as one of the country’s first coeducational institutions, Hamline University in Saint Paul is Minnesota’s oldest university.
Students interested in law have plentiful options at Hamline—the school offers a Legal Studies major and minor, a parallel certificate program and accelerated entry to Hamline’s law school. The university also offers an online B.A. in majors in business or psychology that students can earn in 18 or more months.
All incoming undergraduates are eligible for up to $2,500 in work study programs.
First-year seminars are required at Hamline, and span a variety of topics: Artificial intelligence, the U.S. income tax system and Drag performance are examples of seminar options.
Hamline claims to be the birthplace of intercollegiate basketball, as Hamline hosted the University of Minnesota’s School of Agriculture’s basketball team on February 9, 1895.
name: Hamline University

description:
Seattle Pacific University is a small, private Christian school in Seattle.
Founded by the Free Methodist Church, SPU remains strongly religious, practicing a “historically orthodox” and ”clearly Evangelical” Christianity. A year after graduation, 93% of students were working, in graduate school, the military or a volunteer position.
SPU is undertaking a drastic effort to become more affordable: the university announced a 25% decrease in tuition for the 2021-22 academic year.
The school has attracted attention in 2021 for the board’s hiring policy that is allegedly discriminatory toward LGBTQ+ individuals, leading to a vote of no confidence from the faculty toward leadership.
“Survivor” host Jeff Probst and In-N-Out Burger co-founder Esther Snyder both attended SPU.
name: Seattle Pacific University

description:
Spanning a 65-acre campus 30 miles south of Pittsburg in Washington, PA, Washington & Jefferson College is a liberal arts college known for its long history—dating back to its founding in 1781.
The college offers 33 undergraduate majors, 16 major emphases, and four pre-professional programs. Business, psychology and political science are the most popular majors.
In January between the fall and spring semesters, the college holds JayTerm, a time when students complete an interdisciplinary course outside of normal curriculum and have an opportunity to study abroad or fulfill a professional experience.
About 99% of students receive some form of financial aid. The average institutional aid for incoming freshmen is approximately $30,000.
Through the Magellan Project, W&J provides funding to students to study abroad, fulfill an internship or complete research.
name: Washington & Jefferson College

description:
Founded in 1826 before becoming a member of the State University of New York system in 1948, SUNY at Fredonia is located a 45-minute drive from Buffalo on Lake Erie.
Fredonia offers six education degree options, and 15% of students opt for an education major.
The Fredonia student body is almost entirely from New York, with 50% of undergraduates hailing from western New York.
The arts thrive at Fredonia, with three theaters, two recital halls and three art galleries on campus.
Perhaps the two most famous Fredonia alumni are two 19th-century entrepreneurs—Benjamin Goodrich, founder of the B.F. Goodrich Company, and James H. McGraw, founder of McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, both went to the school.
name: SUNY at Fredonia

description:
Westmont College is a Christian liberal arts school that emphasizes leadership in academia, faith and global affairs. The school’s 111-acre campus is a shuttle ride away from downtown Santa Barbara, CA, as well as Butterfly Beach and East Beach.
Westmont holds Chapel three times a week. There are more than 30 student-led ministries for students to participate in community service.
Westmont offers about 30 undergraduate and 11 pre-professional programs for students to choose from. The most popular majors are kinesiology and business.
Students are encouraged to study abroad. The college offers ten semester-long programs, many of which complement certain majors. Students may also spend a semester at one of 12 other colleges in the Christian College Consortium.
About 95% of students receive scholarships or grants from Westmont. There are numerous merit scholarships, including one that covers 85% of tuition.
name: Westmont College

description:
The largest HBCU in the country, STEM-focused North Carolina A&T State University is in Greensboro, NC.
NC A&T is the top producer of Black engineering graduates, and 13% of students are engineers.There are 54 undergraduate degree programs.
The university has recently seen a rise in donations, receiving $88 million in donations last fiscal year, including a $45 million gift from MacKenzie Scott.
The 2021 NC A&T freshman class includes a unique member: 35-year-old former NBA star J.R. Smith is joining the school’s men’s golf team.
Politician, minister and activist Jesse Jackson graduated from NC A&T, where he was quarterback for the football team, student body president and civil rights leader.
name: North Carolina A&T State University

description:
College of Charleston is a public institution in the heart of South Carolina’s oldest city. Deeply committed to the liberal arts and sciences, the atmosphere is civically and globally-minded.
The college offers 64 majors, 82 minors and 25 interdisciplinary minors, such as data science and environmental and sustainability studies. Many students study business, political science or biology.
The college’s career center is known for its partnerships with large companies. About 67% of the class of 2019 students completed at least one internship, and 81% were employed within one year by the time they graduated.
There are more than 240 clubs on campus for students to join, as well as 28 Greek life chapters.
In the Honors College, students take interdisciplinary courses, engage in local community organizations, meet faculty in the college, and participate in research or internship opportunities.
name: College of Charleston

description:
Wichita State University utilizes its location in the largest city in Kansas to provide a wealth of hands-on experiences for its students.
WSU offers more than 170 majors, including accelerated master’s programs and online degrees. Popular subjects include business, the health professions, engineering and education.
The university is home to more than 30 centers and institutes. WSU is one of the fastest-growing research institutions in the country and boasts over $160 million in annual research funding. Students also take part in internships and co-op programs with more than 450 employers.
Campus life includes more than 200 student organizations, Greek life and Division I athletics. More than 40% are first-generation students.
Freshmen merit scholarships range from $1,000 to $6,000 annually. The Shocker Promise provides last-dollar funding to low-income students from Sedgwick County. WSU also has tuition discount programs for students from 11 Midwestern and Southern states.
name: Wichita State University

description:
Xavier University is a Jesuit Catholic school in the heart of Cincinnati, OH, providing a core curriculum in a Catholic, liberal arts education. True to the school’s Jesuit tradition, Xavier students tally more than 80,000 hours of service annually.
A member of the Division I Big East Conference, Xavier fields 18 varsity teams, known as the Musketeers. The men’s basketball team’s rivalry with the University of Cincinnati’s team, known as the Crosstown Shootout given the schools’ proximity, is one of the best in all of college basketball.
About 20 percent of undergraduates major in the Williams College of Business. Other popular fields of study include nursing, liberal arts and biology.
Nearly all undergraduates receive grant or scholarship aid, some through Xavier’s multicultural scholarships, such as the Weninger Scholarship named after the founder of the first Catholic Church in Cincinnati dedicated to serving the black community.
Former Speaker of the House John Boehner, NBA All-Star David West and Pulitzer Prize-winning author Garry Wills all went to Xavier.
name: Xavier University

description:
A small private college on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the New York School of Interior Design is dedicated to training the next generation of design professionals.
Undergraduate students at NYSID all pursue Bachelor’s of Fine Arts degrees in interior design. Students study historical developments, visual concepts, presentation and a wide range of practical designs for residential and commercial spaces.
NYSID students don’t fit the usual profile: Nearly 90% are women, and the average age is 30.
Students tend to have successful careers after graduation: Within 6 months, 100% of undergraduate alumni were employed or pursuing further education.
organizationName: New York School of Interior Design
name: New York School of Interior Design

description:
Westminster College in Fulton, MO provides an intimate liberal arts experience that focuses on undergraduate success.
Students can choose from 29 majors, as well as pre-professional and dual degree programs. About 15% of students choose to design their own major. The First Year experience includes highlights like a leadership course and assigned peer mentors.
With a 10:1 student-to-faculty ratio, Westminster has a tight-knit community. In fall 2021, the college welcomed its largest freshman class in five years, bringing total enrollment to more than 650 students. The majority of students live on campus, which is enhanced by more than 50 clubs, Greek life and Division II athletics.
Merit scholarships range from $10,000 to $18,000. The G. Robert Muehlhauser Award of Excellence provides one full-tuition award to a high-achieving incoming freshman.
Westminster boasts a 98% placement in jobs or graduate school following graduation.
name: Westminster College (MO)

description:
Founded in 1959 in part thanks to a $6.5 million gift from Ford Motor Company, the University of Michigan-Dearborn is located in the automotive company’s home city of Dearborn, MI.
UM-Dearborn’s 17 research centers and institute span from the Dearborn Artificial Intelligence Research (DAIR) Center to an oral history archive of Holocaust survivors.
Fitting given its Ford ties, Mechanical Engineering is the most popular major. Other popular fields include business and biological and biomedical sciences.
92% of incoming undergraduates receive financial assistance and more than a third of students receive Pell grants.
Of students that entered the workforce immediately after graduation, 90% remained in Michigan, while 8% of graduates chose to pursue graduate school.
name: University of Michigan-Dearborn

description:
Sam Houston State is a large, public research university in Huntsville, TX, that offers a traditional college experience as well as a number of flexible degree offerings.
Undergraduates at SHSU can choose from more than 80 majors, with liberal arts and pre-professional offerings. Many majors, particularly from the school of criminal justice, are available online.
Sam Houston State accommodates a wide variety of students. Around 45% of students are first generation college students, and 75% work while pursuing their degree.
While a small minority of students live on campus, the school maintains an active atmosphere with a large number of student groups, Greek life and traditions like the Bearkat tailgate.
Notable SHSU alumni include broadcast journalist Dan Rather, director Richard Linklater and St. Luke’s Health CEO Melinda Estes.
name: Sam Houston State University

description:
Nova Southeastern University in Fort Lauderdale is Florida’s largest private university with research specializations in healthcare, biotechnology, life sciences, environment and social sciences.
Undergraduates can choose from more than 50 degree programs. Popular programs include the health professions, biology and business. NSU spans eight campuses across the state, as well as a Puerto Rico location.
From research—the university boasts more than $100 million in external funding—to interning with more than 100 corporate partners, NSU students are provided with real-world experience prior to graduating. 92% of graduates participated in experiential learning during their time at NSU.
Nova Southeastern is a Hisapnic-serving institution, and more than half of undergraduates identify as students of color.
82% of the class of 2020 was employed or continuing education within six months of graduating.
name: Nova Southeastern University

description:
The University of Southern Mississippi is a large public university with a flagship campus in Hattiesburg, MS, and a satellite campus on the Mississippi Gulf Coast.
Southern Miss’ 300-acre Hattiesburg campus is centered around the Aubrey K. Lucas Administration Building, affectionately referred to as “The Dome” due to its unique roof.
Southern Miss has the highest Carnegie research classification and registered nursing and teacher education are the two most popular fields of study.
The All-American Rose Garden, equipped with 32 beds of roses, is guarded by a large golden eagle statue.
Southern Miss’s two most famous alumni, Pro Football Hall of Fame quarterback Brett Favre and singer Jimmy Buffett share a close connection: Favre inducted Buffett into the Southern Miss Alumni Hall of Fame in 2018.
name: University of Southern Mississippi

description:
This private liberal arts college, located in Staten Island, NY, gives students a sheltered college campus experience in close proximity to Manhattan.
Wagner offers 32 undergraduate majors for students to choose from. Almost one-third of students major in nursing, while many students also major in drama and business.
By the spring of senior year, 100% of students have an internship or other practicum under their belt. About 38% of students study abroad, and 100% participate in research with faculty.
There are 65 clubs and organizations for students to join, including 10 academic honor societies, nine Greek life chapters, and six different service organizations.
About 90% of students receive some form of financial aid. All applicants are automatically considered for merit scholarships, with the highest equaling $19,000.
name: Wagner College

description:
Louisiana Tech University is a STEM-focused public research institution in Ruston, LA, a college town in the northwest part of the state.
Louisiana Tech does have a College of Liberal Arts, though STEM programs still dominate its academic scene. Biology, computer science and mechanical engineering are the most popular majors.
The Thingery is a makerspace located on campus and offers workshops on topics from 3D modeling to animation.
Each spring, Louisiana Tech hosts a new venture competition, with the top student entrepreneur teams earning the title of TOP DOG.
Pro Football Hall of Famer Terry Bradshaw and Duck Dynasty star Phil Robertson both went to Louisiana Tech.
name: Louisiana Tech University

description:
Baldwin Wallace University in Berea, OH is a private institution that takes experiential learning seriously—students are required to take part in 30 hours of meaningful learning activities, from internships to research to studying abroad.
Undergraduates can choose from over 80 majors and seven pre-professional programs. Business, the performing arts and the health professions are among popular areas of study. The university is also home to a music conservatory.
There are more than 100 student organizations and Greek life on campus. BW students take part in more than 10,000 hours of service in the Greater Cleveland area and beyond.
Merit scholarships range from $12,000 to $21,000. BW has a four year graduation guarantee, whereby it will cover tuition if a student takes longer than four years to complete their degree.
Some 64% of the class of 2020 are employed, 23% are continuing their education and the majority live in Ohio. In 2021, BW welcomed its largest freshman class of 720 students since 2015.
name: Baldwin Wallace University

description:
A public research institution in downtown Huntington, WV, Marshall University is named for Chief Justice of the Supreme Court John Marshall.
Of its 52 undergraduate degree options, biology, business administration and nursing are among the most popular.
Over 80% of faculty are full-time and a similar percentage of students receive institutional grants or scholarships.
Marshall has more than 200 student organizations, including Greek life.
The 2006 feature film “We are Marshall” starring Matthew McConaughey is based on the aftermath of the 1970 plane crash that claimed the lives of most of Marshall’s football program.
name: Marshall University

description:
La Salle University is a Catholic liberal arts institution in Philadelphia that aims to provide a well-rounded education for a diverse campus: Students of color constitute some 50% of the student body and 45% receive Pell Grants.
The university has 38 undergraduate fields of study and pre-professional programs. Nursing and marketing are among the most popular majors.
La Salle offers full-tuition merit scholarships for some first-year students, as well as a $5,000 scholarship for students who have shown dedication to community service.
There are about 175 clubs and organizations on campus, including 13 club sports, 17 honor societies and more than two dozen academic clubs.
The La Salle Explorers compete in 17 NCAA Division I sports teams. Since 1948, 16 La Salle University student athletes have appeared in the Olympics, three of whom earned gold medals.
name: La Salle University

description:
Washington College in Chestertown, MD, is the first chartered college in the sovereign United States, upholding a standard of success and experiential learning for over 230 years.
Students can choose from over 20 majors and pre-professional programs in health and law. The liberal arts curriculum places a heavy emphasis on writing and communication.
The Center for Environment and Society runs programs like the “Chesapeake Semester,” a signature experience that allows students to take part in intensive study, fieldwork and outdoor adventure at North America’s largest estuary. Students can also conduct research at the living field lab, bird observatory and archaeology lab.
Merit scholarships with automatic consideration range up to $35,000 annually.
65% of the class of 2020 is employed, and almost half remain in Maryland. 21% of the class is continuing their education.
name: Washington College

description:
With a dedication to educating students on traditional and contemporary formats of music, Berklee College of Music in Boston, MA, is one of the nation’s most prestigious institutions for performing arts.
The college offers 12 majors spanning many aspects of the music industry, from performance to composition to music production.
Berklee has more than 350 ensemble and practice rooms on campus. Students also have opportunities to perform at a variety of venues at the school, including a 1,200-seat concert hall.
About 40% of entering campus students receive institutional financial aid, covering an average of 40% of tuition. All entering students are automatically considered for merit scholarships, including one covering full tuition, housing, meal plan and fees for high achieving musicians with the financial need.
More than 300 Grammy award winners call Berklee their alma mater, including big pop artists such as John Mayer and Charlie Puth.
name: Berklee College of Music

description:
St. John’s College in Annapolis, MD is known for its unique liberal arts curriculum focused on the most important books and ideas of Western civilization.
The college offers a bachelor’s degree in the liberal arts, as well as combined degrees in eastern classics, liberal arts and law. Rather than majors, students study subjects, including philosophy, theology, natural sciences, history, Greek, French, mathematics, music and arts. All classes are conducted seminar-style with 20 or fewer students.
Arts and culture are a large part of campus life, from the Freshman Chorus, a mandatory singing group, to Collegium, a tradition that gives students and faculty an opportunity to show off their musical talents.
The college provides $4,000 stipends for unpaid summer internshipsTuition has been held flat at $35,000 since 2019, and merit scholarships can range up to full tuition.
Approximately three-quarters of alumni are employed within six months of graduation.
name: St. John's College, Annapolis

description:
A large public school, Northern Kentucky University is located seven miles southeast of Cincinnati, OH, in suburban Highland Heights, KY.
NKU’s 70-plus majors span from 3D Digital Design to Sports Business and Event Management.
Each semester, certain courses participate in the Mayerson Student Philanthropy Project, in which classmates are given a sum of money and decide which non-profit to donate to.
Greek life is popular at NKU, with more than 1,000 students belonging to one of the 23 fraternities and sororities on campus.
Academy Award-winning actor George Clooney attended NKU, where he majored in Broadcast Journalism before dropping out of school to pursue a career in acting.
name: Northern Kentucky University

description:
Lewis and Clark College in Portland, OR, is a private liberal arts college that encourages its students to go on intellectual expeditions.
Lewis and Clark offers over 20 majors, the most popular of which include psychology, international affairs and sociology/anthropology. One-third of students major in STEM fields.
With an intimate 12:1 student-to-faculty ratio, students get the most out of their studies. Outside of the classroom, more than 300 students study abroad in over 20 locations annually. The college’s Portland location provides students with a wealth of extracurricular and professional experiences.
About one-third of undergraduates are students of color. 20% are Pell Grant-eligible and 18% are first-generation.
Within six months of graduating, 72% of the class of 2020 was employed and 24% were continuing their education.
name: Lewis & Clark College

description:
A mid-sized public university, the University of Texas of the Permian Basin is located in Odessa, TX, a city in west Texas.
Half of the UTPB student body is Hispanic, qualifying the school as a Hispanic-serving institution.
UTPB has an extensive core curriculum, covering mathematics, creative arts, physical sciences and more.
The Texas Water and Energy Institute deals with issues regarding produced water, wastewater and drinking water. The institute hosts the Water Lecture Series that brings leaders in the industry to campus.
There is a Stonehenge replica on campus, consisting of 20-ton limestone slabs.
organizationName: The University of Texas of the Permian Basin
name: The University of Texas of the Permian Basin

description:
The second-largest member of the University System of Georgia, Kennesaw State University is a 30-minute drive north of Atlanta in Kennesaw, GA.
About 20% of students major in the Coles College of Business, named for Great American Cookie Company founder and former Caribou Coffee CEO Michael Coles.
Formerly a commuter school, KSU now houses more than 5,000 students.
The KSU Owls field 18 Division I varsity athletic teams, competing in the Atlantic Sun Conference in every sport except for football, which plays in the Big South Conference.
There are more than 125,000 members of the KSU alumni network.
name: Kennesaw State University

description:
Grand Valley State University is a large public institution 12 miles west of Grand Rapids in Allendale, Michigan.
GVSU’s main campus sits on more than 1,000 acres of land, and the school operates seven other locations throughout Michigan.
A quarter of students participate in faculty-led research.
The GVSU Lakers are a Division II athletic powerhouse. Their 25 team and 77 individual national championships are among the 15 most of any Division II school. The Lakers’ women’s soccer and women’s cross country teams are the school’s most dominant sports, each with four national titles since 2014.
There are more than 130,000 GVSU alumni, three-quarters of whom live in Michigan.
name: Grand Valley State University

description:
Part of the City University of New York system, the College of Staten Island is located on the largest campus in New York City and provides students with learning and research opportunities.
Undergraduates can choose from over 50 majors. Popular programs include psychology, business, English and nursing. CSI also has another campus in Staten Island and a tech incubator.
CSI has state-of-the-art equipment and facilities in more than 70 science labs, including the CUNY High Performance Computing Center and the Center for Developmental Neuroscience and Developmental Disabilities.
Campus life is accented by more than 50 student organizations. More than half of undergraduates are from an underrepresented background, and the majority of students hail from Staten Island.
Merit-based scholarships are offered through the college’s special programs, including the Verrazzano School honors program and the Teacher Education Honors Academy for aspiring math and science middle and high school teachers.
name: CUNY, College of Staten Island

description:
The King’s College is a Christian liberal arts college located in New York City’s Financial District.
The college offers nine majors in business, communications and the liberal arts. King’s Crossover is a hybrid program that lets students complete up to two years of coursework online followed by a minimum of two years in New York.
TKC places an emphasis on experiential learning, with 87% of graduates completing internships during their time at the college.
Faith is a cornerstone of student life at TKC, coming together for public scripture readings and holding dedicated days of fasting and prayer. The House System is made of smaller student-led cohorts who organize events and service opportunities for others.
99% of alumni are employed or in graduate school within six months of graduating.
name: The King's College

description:
Saint Mary’s College in Notre Dame, IN, is a tight-knit women’s college sponsored by the Sisters of the Holy Cross that offers intimate learning experiences.
Undergraduates can choose from over 30 majors. Popular programs include nursing, business and psychology. Through a partnership with nearby Notre Dame University, Saint Mary’s students are able to take classes at the university, as well as take part in a five-year dual degree engineering program.
More than 80% of seniors participate in an internship, co-op, field experience, student teaching or clinical placement, and over half of students study abroad. Between Saint Mary’s and Notre Dame, there are more than 500 student organizations to take part in.
Saint Mary’s offers merit awards ranging up to $30,000.
About 93% of recent alumnae are either employed full time or enrolled in graduate school one year following graduation.
name: Saint Mary's College (IN)

description:
Affiliated with the United Methodist Church, High Point University in High Point, NC, stresses the importance of building leadership skills and development under a growth mindset.
High Point University has 63 undergraduate majors to choose from. Undergraduate students can participate in student-faculty research and creative works across a variety of disciplines.
Every incoming student is paired with a peer mentor, an upperclassman who provides advice to help transition students into college. For the class of 2020, 97% of students were employed or enrolled in graduate school within six months of graduation.
The university offers merit scholarships, with the highest valued between $30,000 and the full cost of tuition. There is also a $1,000 award for students who became Eagle Scouts in the Boy Scouts or received the Gold Award in the Girl Scouts.
name: High Point University

description:
The University of Alaska, Anchorage is the largest university in The Last Frontier.
91% of the student body are Alaska residents, though UAA has a strong international presence, with students from 89 different countries represented.
UAA’s Institute for Circumpolar Health focuses on finding solutions for rural healthcare in Alaska and other circumpolar regions.
Business Administration, Public Health and Psychology are among the most popular majors.
The school’s hockey program will return in the 2022-23 season after raising $3 million to save the program. In 2020, the University of Alaska’s Board of Regents had decided to eliminate the school’s Division I hockey program due to financial reasons.
name: University of Alaska, Anchorage

description:
Mercer University in Macon, GA is a private university that encourages research and service through the liberal arts and pre-professional development.
Mercer offers more than 130 academic programs in 12 degree-granting schools and colleges, including 14 pre-professional programs in the health sciences and accelerated degree programs in engineering, law, accounting and business administration. Popular programs include nursing, engineering and biology.
Classroom knowledge is put into practice at Mercer. More than 70% of students participate in at least one internship, over 30% of students engage in undergraduate research and thousands of students and faculty take part in Mercer on Mission international service-learning trips.
Mercer pride is brought to life through the more than 140 student organizations and NCAA Division I athletics. In addition to the traditional undergraduate experience in Macon, students can get involved at the graduate and professional campus in Atlanta.
About 96% of the class of 2020 are employed or in graduate school. The School of Music and the College of Nursing had 100% career outcomes for 2020 graduates.
name: Mercer University

description:
A member of the Pennsylvania State System, West Chester University is a large public school in the Philadelphia suburb of West Chester, PA.
West Chester, originally founded as West Chester Normal School in 1871, will celebrate its 150th anniversary this fall.
The school was a teacher’s college for the first half of its existence. This legacy remains at West Chester, as nearly 10% of students major in Education. Psychology is the top major, followed by teacher education and business administration.
Abolitionist Frederick Douglass gave his last public lecture at West Chester, and the university’s Frederick Douglass Institute for multicultural studies is named in his honor.
First Lady Jill Biden received a Master’s degree in Education from West Chester in 1981.
name: West Chester University of Pennsylvania

description:
This private Jesuit institution in Buffalo, NY, Canisius College stresses the importance of immersive learning and gives many opportunities for students to get hands-on experience through global travel and research.
There are more than 45 majors for students to choose from. Animal behavior is the most popular program, closely followed by accounting and psychology. Canisius has a rigorous core curriculum that encompasses liberal arts and cross-disciplinary skills such as ethical decision-making and cultural competency.
Canisius has more than 90 student organizations, including a large variety of academic clubs and honor societies.
The college offers merit scholarships of up to $16,000 for incoming freshmen. There are additional scholarships available for students in the fine arts department, as well as a mission- and service-based scholarship program.
name: Canisius College

description:
Millsaps College in Jackson, MS is a small, private college supported by the Methodist Church with a robust liberal arts curriculum.
Students can choose from over 30 majors. An intimate 9-to-1 student-to-faculty ratio provides students with individualized attention in the classroom. Millsaps is also home to a management school that offers graduate degrees.
Students can take part in over 60 clubs and organizations, including Greek life. Students balance the city life that comes with living in the state’s capital and residential living—over 80% of students reside on the 100-acre campus.
Automatic merit awards range from $18,000 to $33,000.
Over 90% of students are employed or in graduate school within six months of graduating.
name: Millsaps College

description:
A member of the State University of New York system in remote Cortland, NY, SUNY Cortland is dedicated to producing the next generation of teachers.
SUNY Cortland was founded as a normal school in 1868 and was exclusively a teacher’s college until 1961.
Today, more than a quarter of students major in education and SUNY Cortland produces the most number of teacher certification candidates in New York State.
95% of SUNY Cortland students are from New York, though the university offers grants of up to $7,500 annually to attract out-of-state and international students.
The school’s unique Red Dragons nickname draws its inspiration from Mobil’s old flying red-horse logo, suggested by a football team manager in 1933.
name: SUNY Cortland

description:
Originally an extension of the College of William and Mary, Old Dominion University is an independent public research university in Norfolk, VA.
About 25% of ODU students are military-affiliated, and the university consistently ranks as one of the country’s most military-friendly colleges.
ODU’s coastal location and institutes including the International Maritime Institute and the Center for Coastal Physical Oceanography enable it to be a leader in nautical research.
The ODU library system has more than three million volumes in its physical collection.
Former MLB Most Valuable Player Justin Verlander and Basketball Hall of Famer Nancy Lieberman are both ODU alumni.
name: Old Dominion University

description:
Messiah University is a private institution in Mechanicsburg, PA, committed to educating through the Christian faith.
Undergraduates can choose from approximately 70 majors, including accelerated partner programs with the University of the Sciences and Carnegie Mellon University. Popular programs include the health professions, education and business.
Students agree to the “Community Covenant,” which provides a Biblical framework and context for the community. Chapel services are held three days a week—attendance is required 14 times per semester—and domestic and international service projects, internships and performances are part of student life.
All undergraduate students receive financial aid, with scholarships for multicultural students and those in the honors program.
Of the 74% of respondents in the Class of 2020, 100% report being employed or in a graduate or professional program within six to nine months after graduation. Of those going to graduate school, approximately half were studying in STEM fields.
name: Messiah University

description:
St. Joseph’s College is a private institution founded by the Congregation of the Sisters of St. Joseph with campuses in Brooklyn and Long Island, NY.
The college offers over 50 undergraduate majors, including dual degree programs. Popular areas of study include education, business and the health professions. SJC also offers online programs for undergraduate and graduate studies.
SJC is committed to service, and students take part in hundreds of local, national and global community service and service-learning projects.
There are more than 25 student organizations, including Greek life. Located in the vibrant city, students have access to all of the benefits of New York City at either campus.
Merit awards range up to at least $17,000 annually. The college implemented a tuition freeze amid the Covid-19 pandemic.
name: St. Joseph's College (NY)

description:
Located in the foothills of the Cascade and Siskiyou Mountains, Southern Oregon University in Ashland, OR, is a public university offering a range of studies and opportunities for outdoor adventures.
Undergraduates can choose from over 40 degree programs, including accelerated three-year degrees, pre-professional programs and online options. Business, psychology, education and theater arts are among popular majors.
Ashland is known for its natural beauty, including lakes, rivers, mountains and caves. Taking note of its natural surroundings, the university has been nationally recognized for its sustainability efforts; it was the first university in the country to be certified as a Bee Campus USA and is designated a Tree Campus by the Arbor Day foundation.
Merit awards range from $2,000 to $5,000 annually for non-residents, $1,000 to $3,500 annually for students participating in the Western Undergraduate Exchange, and $2,000 to $5,000 annually for residents. The Jackson/Josephine Pledge Program provides a tuition discount and mentoring for high school graduates from these areas, and students from diverse backgrounds are eligible for an annual $5,000 scholarship.
About 85% of recent graduates are employed or continuing their education.
name: Southern Oregon University

description:
A midsize, public university in Laredo, TX, Texas A&M International specializes in serving the education needs of the multilingual, multicultural US-Mexico border.
TAMIU offers more than 60 undergraduate majors, including a larger number of majors in business, education and health careers.
Students can lean into TAMIU’s specialties with a minor in International Leadership, which requires a broad survey of courses in communications, management and politics.
The TAMIU Dustdevils compete in 11 NCAA D2 sports.
Notable alumni include US Congressman Henry Cuellar, oil and gas billionaire Rodney Lewis and author Norma Elia Cantu.
name: Texas A & M International University

description:
At Western Kentucky University, home to the “Hilltoppers,” students don’t just climb the hill—they climb the ladder of success.
Undergraduates can choose from over 100 majors and pre-professional programs across five colleges. The university has locations across the state and offers over 50 online degrees.
Business, the health professions and education are popular subjects, and the university is known for its journalism program.
The university offers over 350 student organizations, more than 30 fraternities and sororities, community service opportunities and Division I sports.
Academic merit awards range from $2,500 to $8,000 annually. WKU guarantees that tuition is covered for entering freshmen from Kentucky who receive Pell Grant assistance. In 2020–21, students won more than $600,000 in funding. Of successful applications, 81% were submitted by Pell Grant recipients, 54% were submitted by first-generation college students and 40% were submitted by minority students.
name: Western Kentucky University

description:
Founded as the first institution in Kansas, Baker University is a private university affiliated with the United Methodist Church that prides itself on its tight-knit community.
Baker offers about 40 areas of study. Popular programs include business, exercise science and elementary education.
Baker students are active outside of the classroom; 93% are involved in clubs, athletics, internships or study abroad.
Merit awards range from $10,000 to $18,000. Baker also offers competitive scholarships, like the prestigious Harter award, providing full tuition and the opportunity to study at Harlaxton College in England. The Lake Scholarship is a need-based award that covers the cost of attendance.
Almost all of recent graduates—99%—are employed or in graduate school.
name: Baker University

description:
Florida Southern is a small, private liberal arts college in Lakeland, FL, affiliated with the Methodist church that prides itself on its tight community and academic rigor.
The school’s 113-acre campus in Central Florida is home to the “Child of the Sun,” a collection of offices, chapels, and a library designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. The Roux Library was designed by Wright’s protege Nils Schweizer.
Students can choose from around 40 majors, including the appropriately Floridian degree in Citrus and Horticultural Science. The school offers a number of liberal arts degrees, as well as professional programs in nursing, sports business management and marketing.
