The “Junior Journey” guarantees that all students with four full-time semesters under their belts will have the opportunity to study abroad.
Florida Southern also promises to help every student get an internship during their education. The school maintains a relationship with the internship-coordinating Washington Center.
name: Florida Southern College

description:
University of Wisconsin, Platteville is a public university with specializations in STEM and agriculture that prides itself on student-centered experiences.
Undergraduates can choose from over 50 majors, as well as pre-professional and online programs. Popular programs include mechanical engineering, criminal justice and industrial technology management. The university also has two other campuses in Baraboo Sauk County and Richland.
About 90% of students participate in at least one internship, co-op, or experiential learning experience before graduating.
The highly competitive Chancellor’s Scholarship awards up to full tuition and fees, and students from diverse backgrounds are eligible for an annual $2,500 scholarship. The Pioneer Pledge guarantees that room and board is covered for incoming freshmen who are Wisconsin residents and are Pell Grant-eligible.
Over 90% of graduates remain in the Midwest.
name: University of Wisconsin-Platteville

description:
Saint Martin’s University in Lacey, WA, one of 13 Benedictine colleges and universities in the United States and Canada, prides itself on hands-on experiences and career preparation.
Students can choose from 60 programs, including pre-health majors, pre-professional pathways, accelerated bachelor's/master's and an intensive English as a Second Language program. Popular majors include business administration, mechanical engineering and psychology.
The university offers faculty-led study abroad programs and ambassador programs providing international volunteer opportunities. Scholars Day is an annual conference that features student research and creative work.
The Saints Promise program guarantees students a three-month paid internship if they do not secure enrollment within six months of graduation or tuition-free enrollment to a graduate program for one semester.
Saint Martin’s awards over $20 million in scholarships ranging from $100 to full tuition.
name: Saint Martin's University

description:
A Catholic school in Fairfield, CT, Sacred Heart University stresses the importance of service.
SHU owns the highly rated Great River Golf Club 11 miles away from campus. Students at the Welch College of Business & Technology can receive golf lessons and receive discounted rates on rounds of golf.
Nursing, psychology and exercise science are the most popular majors.
SHU has more than 100 partnerships with non-profit organizations and other organizations, with volunteer opportunities including tutoring and mentoring programs with local students and a Habitat for Humanity chapter.
The most common fields for SHU graduates are physical therapy, accounting and occupational therapy. The pre-health emphasis is strong at SHU, as the five most common alumni employers are all Connecticut health systems.
name: Sacred Heart University

description:
SUNY Oneonta is a public college within the State University of New York system with pre-professional specializations.
Undergraduates can choose from over 40 majors, as well as pre-health and pre-law advising tracks. Business, education and communications are among popular programs. The college also offers cooperative programs with other institutions, like with Clarkson University for an MBA, a one-year program at the Fashion Institute of Technology and 3-2 engineering programs with a number of engineering schools.
SUNY Oneonta offers 13 study abroad programs and other short-term faculty-led trips. More than 500 students complete internships annually.
Students can engage with more than 100 student organizations and Greek life. Oneonta is located among the foothills of the Catskill Mountains.
SUNY Oneonta awarded more than $5.7 million in scholarships in 2020–21. Merit awards range up to $20,000 over four years for New York residents and $32,000 for students coming from out of state.
name: SUNY, College at Oneonta

description:
Bowie State University, Maryland’s first historically Black public university, provides students with experiential learning opportunities to prepare them for their careers.
Undergraduates can choose from over 20 majors across four colleges. Popular programs include business administration, criminal justice and communications. Bowie is home to Maryland’s first program in hip-hop studies and visual culture.
The Entrepreneurship Academy helps students develop entrepreneurial skills through incubator programs and coaching, and undergraduates are able to conduct original research with faculty mentors through the Semester-based Undergraduate Research Institute.
Student life is accented by 50 clubs and more than 10 Greek letter organizations. The university is located less than an hour away from Annapolis, MD and Washington, D.C., providing students with easy access to internships and cultural experiences.
In 2020, billionaire MacKenzie Scott donated $25 million to the university—the largest in BSU’s history—which will go toward its endowment.
name: Bowie State University

description:
Located on the shore of Lake Ontario, SUNY College at Oswego is a public college that provides students with a wide range of hands-on experiences without compromising individualized attention.
Undergraduates can choose from about 60 majors, as well as five-year accelerated degrees. Business, communications and education are the most popular areas of study. SUNY Oswego also has a Syracuse campus with programs designed for transfer and returning students.
About 800 students complete internships and co-ops annually, and students can take part in more than 80 study abroad programs.
SUNY Oswego annually provides more than $6.5 million in merit-based scholarships. The Oswego Guarantee promises no increase in the cost of room or meal plans for four consecutive academic years. Students who graduate on time receive a $300 bonus from the college.
About 94% of graduates are employed or continuing their education.
name: SUNY College at Oswego

description:
Growing from a small training school for teachers to a comprehensive university, the University of Central Missouri in Warrensburg, MO is one of the oldest universities in the state.
UCM offers more than 150 degree programs across four colleges that house 16 schools. Popular programs include nursing, criminal justice and education. The Lee’s Summit campus is geared toward undergraduate completion, and the university also offers fully online programs.
UCM has more than 200 student organizations, Division II athletics and Greek life. More than 87% of undergraduates hail from Missouri.
The university awards about $21 million in institutional aid and $1.3 million in scholarships annually.
About 95% of the class of 2020 is working or continuing their education within six months of graduating.
name: University of Central Missouri

description:
Located in the heart of Jersey City, Saint Peter’s University is New Jersey’s only Jesuit university.
Undergraduates can choose from over 50 majors, as well as pre-professional programs with the New Jersey Institute of Technology, Rutgers University, Seton Hall University and the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. Popular majors include biology, business and criminal justice.
Saint Peter’s also offers classes in New York City, utilizing its close proximity to provide students with robust job and internship opportunities.
In line with its Jesuit values, the university runs a number of community service projects that over 700 students take part in annually. Campus ministry runs a robust retreat program to encourage spiritual discovery.
Saint Peter’s is a Hispanic-serving institution, with almost half of the student body identifying as such. The majority of students hail from New Jersey, and about half are Pell Grant recipients.
name: Saint Peter's University

description:
The largest institution among the 13-school Christian College Consortium, Bethel University is a private Evangelical Christian college located in suburban Arden Hills, MN.
A 20-minute drive from Minneapolis and St. Paul, Bethel’s lakeside campus spans 247 acres.
Student life is dictated by Bethel’s “Covenant for Life Together,” which discourages alcoholic consumption, gambling, homosexual acts and extramarital intercourse.
Nursing is the most popular major at Bethel, and the integration of Christian faith is emphasized in the nursing education.
Bethel offers 11 pre-professional programs, including pre-law, actuarial science, pre-chiropractic medicine and pre-physical therapy.
name: Bethel University

description:
Located in downtown Chicago, the School of the Art Institute of Chicago is one of the oldest accredited independent schools of art and design in the country.
SAIC has an open curriculum, meaning students do not declare a major. In addition to courses related to the chosen discipline, students are required to take liberal arts courses. Undergraduates graduate with either a Bachelor of Fine Arts or Bachelor of Arts degree.
SAIC is home to the largest school-museum campus in the country. Students have access to photography and filmmaking equipment, state-of-the-art 3D printing and laser cutting facilities, and galleries to share their work.
Students are required to complete an off-campus experience, either through internships or study abroad programs.
SAIC is a top producer of Fulbright Scholars among art and design schools, receiving 11 awards in the last five years. Notable artists who studied at the school include Georgia O’Keeffe and Jeff Koons. Author David Sedaris is also an alum.
organizationName: School of the Art Institute of Chicago
name: School of the Art Institute of Chicago

description:
One of six senior military colleges in the U.S., the University of North Georgia operates five campuses across the northern part of the state, with a main campus in Dahlonega.
The university operates a large Army ROTC program, and UNG’s Corps of Cadets is known as the Boar’s Head Brigade.
Biology, management and criminal justice are among UNG’s most popular majors.
Niche named UNG one of the most conservative colleges in the nation, and the university is home to the Politically Incorrect Club, as well as chapters of the College Democrats and College Republicans.
Over the last five years, UNG has graduated more than 600 commissioned cadets.
name: University of North Georgia

description:
Located on an island in Orono, ME, the University of Maine is the state’s premier public research institution with specializations in forestry, marine sciences, climate change and STEM.
The university offers more than 100 majors, minors and other academic programs. Business, engineering and education are among popular areas of study. UMaine also has a regional campus in Machias and offers fully online degrees.
The land, sea and space grant institution received a record-breaking $133 million in research and development funding in 2021. The university encourages undergraduates to apply for $1,200 fellowships to help fund their research endeavors.
Home to Maine’s only Division I athletics program, there is plenty of pride for the Black Bears. In addition to the more than 200 organizations, students take advantage of the 15 miles of running, biking and cross-country skiing trails on campus and countless recreational activities.
Consideration for scholarships places an emphasis on high school GPA and the rigor of completed courses, and these awards can range up to full tuition. Residents from other New England states also qualify for lower tuition.
name: University of Maine

description:
Affiliated with the United Methodist Church, North Central College is a small liberal arts school 30 miles west of Chicago in Naperville, IL.
North Central offers a variety of scholarships, including a $1,000 alumni referral scholarship and a $3,000 scholarship for children of Methodist ministers.
Among the North Central Class of 2019, the three most common career fields are sales and marketing, accounting, banking, finance and insurance and K-12 education.
The North Central Cardinals field 25 varsity sports teams and are among the most decorated athletic programs in all of Division III.
The Cardinals’ 33 team national championships and 92 individual national championships are both good for top-10 in Division III history.
name: North Central College

description:
Lawrence Technological University in Southfield, MI provides students with an intimate academic experience focused on STEM.
Undergraduates can choose from over 30 majors across four colleges, as well as dual degree, pre-professional and fully online programs. Mechanical engineering, architecture and computer science are among the most popular majors. In June, LTU opened the Specs Howard School of Media Arts, which is focused on broadcast, digital media and graphic design.
The majority of students hail from Michigan, and over half of students transfer in. The tight-knit community comes together through 60 clubs, including Greek life.
Incoming freshmen are considered for merit scholarships ranging from $4,500 to $16,000 annually. All undergraduates receive laptops for the academic year.
Within six months of graduating, 86% of LTU students have jobs in their field; the job placement rate is 94% for engineering majors.
name: Lawrence Technological University

description:
New Jersey City University is a public university that grew from a training school for teachers to a comprehensive institution offering degrees in pre-professional and interdisciplinary fields.
NJCU's College of Arts and Sciences, Education, Professional Studies, and School of Business offer over 40 undergraduate degree programs. Popular majors include biology, management and psychology. NJCU has three other locations in the state, including its newest Fort Monmouth location, which opened in August 2021.
NJCU has over 20 student organizations, Division III athletics and Greek life. Campus is located a short train ride from New York City, providing students with unlimited professional and extracurricular experiences.
The university is a Hispanic-serving institution, with over 40% of students identifying as such. Over half of students are Pell Grant recipients.
NJCU provides more than $20 million in financial and merit aid annually. The university offers a limited number of prestigious scholarships to incoming students.
name: New Jersey City University

description:
Celebrating its 50th anniversary this year, the University of Texas at Tyler has specializations in nursing, business, engineering, arts and sciences, pharmacy, pre-med and teacher education.
Undergraduates can choose from more than 40 degrees across six academic colleges. Nursing, education and management are the most popular majors. UT Tyler has instructional sites for the health sciences and engineering across Texas.
The college is home to almost 20 research centers and institutes. Over 30% of the Class of 2020 conducted independent research and 22% worked one-on-one with a professor to conduct research.
Even though it is one of the smallest institutions in the UT system, UT Tyler has a wealth of activities, including more than 100 student organizations, Greek life and Division III sports.
UT Tyler offers a number of merit scholarships that cover full tuition and fees. Texas students whose parent's adjusted gross income is $80,000 or lower also have full tuition and fees covered.
organizationName: The University of Texas at Tyler
name: The University of Texas at Tyler

description:
Wheaton College in Norton, MA, is a small liberal arts college that prides itself on a personalized education and co-curricular experiences.
Students can choose from over 100 majors and minors. Popular programs include business, psychology and biology. Wheaton also offers dual degree programs in engineering and communications with nearby institutions.
Wheaton stresses global education: About half of students study abroad, and Wheaton was the first college in the world to offer a study abroad program in Bhutan.
There are over 100 student organizations on campus. Students can also engage with each other through theme houses, where residence is based around shared interests like the outdoors or politics.
Six months after graduation, 97% of alumni in the five most recent classes were employed, pursuing further education or participating in internships, fellowships or service opportunities.
name: Wheaton College (MA)

description:
For more than 100 years, the Otis College of Art and Design has used the vibrant energy of Los Angeles to educate rising artists.
Otis offers Bachelor of Fine Arts degrees in communication arts, digital media, environmental design, fashion design, fine arts, product design and toy design. Before students select a major, they spend the first year learning art and design basics. Students also take liberal arts and science and service-oriented courses.
Students have 24-hour access to facilities including painting, ceramics, lighting and sculpture studios, as well as photography, video and printmaking labs. All students showcase their work in exhibitions before graduating.
Students can spend a semester or a year on exchange at partner art and design colleges in the U.S., Canada and Europe. Almost 70% of seniors said they completed freelance work while at Otis.
About 30% of Otis students are first-generation, and almost one-quarter are international students. Students of color make up nearly 62% of the student body.
organizationName: Otis College of Art and Design
name: Otis College of Art and Design

description:
The University of Central Arkansas in Conway, AR, located about a half hour away from the state’s capital, provides students with a wealth of options to learn outside of the traditional classroom setting.
Students can choose from more than 150 programs of study. The Colleges of Health and Behavioral Sciences; Arts, Humanities and Social Sciences; and Business have the largest enrollments. The university opened a new state-of-the-art 80,000-square-foot Integrated Health Sciences Building in August.
Undergraduates are encouraged to take part in research and can apply for stipends of at least $2,000 for funding and travel costs. UCA also offers a number of faculty-led international programs in locations like Kenya, Austria and Rwanda.
Students can take part in over 200 organizations, including Greek life and Division I athletics. About 86% of students hail from Arkansas.
Merit scholarships range from $1,500 to $8,500. Students in either the Schedler Honors College or University Scholars Program are eligible for a stipend each semester and a private room upgrade.
name: University of Central Arkansas

description:
St. Mary’s University is a small private Catholic Marianist university in San Antonio, Texas.
The campus is five miles from The Alamo and the San Antonio River Walk.
The St. Mary’s core is extensive, consisting of 10 classes that provide foundations in the arts, religion, service, natural science, ethics and history.
St. Mary’s Catholic background informs much of campus life, with classes canceled for school-wide masses on All Saint’s Day and Ash Wednesday and a 40 Days of Service community service program during Lent.
Notable St. Mary’s alumni include Senator and former Majority Whip John Cornyn and Emmy-award winning journalist John Quiñones.
name: St. Mary's University (TX)

description:
Central Connecticut State University is the state’s oldest publicly funded university, serving the community for over 170 years.
Undergraduates can choose from over 80 degree programs across four colleges and schools: Arts and Sciences, Business, Education and Professional Studies, and Engineering, Science and Technology. Computer science, business/marketing and education are the top majors.
CCSU has over 20 partnerships and exchanges in 17 countries and offers courses abroad in the winter, spring and summer sessions. CCSU also offers a six-month co-op employment program for students.
There are over 100 student organizations and NCAA Division I sports at the university. The majority of students hail from Connecticut, and less than a quarter live on campus. Campus is located about 15 minutes from Hartford, the state capital, and two hours from New York City and Boston.
More than 85% of CCSU graduates remain in Connecticut.
name: Central Connecticut State University

description:
Slippery Rock University of Pennsylvania is a public university that has been providing students with a rock-solid base for their careers for over 130 years.
SRU offers more than 150 undergraduate majors and minors across four colleges. Popular majors include exercise and rehabilitative science, special education and safety management.
Learning is encouraged outside of the classroom. Students can apply for up to $1,000 in funds to support research or a scholarly project in collaboration with a faculty or staff member, and hundreds of students study abroad annually.
SRU was recognized with a 2020 Carnegie Community Engagement Classification, signifying high levels of volunteerism. Over 1,000 students take part in service-learning courses and sponsors the Bonner Leader Program, a scholarship program for students engaged in community service.
Students engage in more than 150 clubs, Greek life and Division II sports. The 660-acre campus is less than an hour from Pittsburgh, and about 90% of students hail from Pennsylvania.
name: Slippery Rock University of Pennsylvania

description:
Metropolitan State University has been committed to serving both traditional and non-traditional students in the Twin Cities for 50 years.
MSU offers more than 50 undergraduate programs. Individualized studies, psychology and nursing are among the most popular majors.
Over half of undergraduates are enrolled part-time and are above 25. The university offers credit for university-level learning from life and work experiences, flexible scheduling and online and hybrid class options to cater to post-traditional students.
Metro State is an Asian American and Native American Pacific-Islander Serving Institution, and people of color make up about half of the student body.
On average over the last five years, about 69% of graduates are in related employment one year following graduation.
name: Metropolitan State University

description:
The University of Texas at El Paso is a comprehensive research university that enrolls a high percentage of Hispanic students.
Undergraduates can choose from over 70 degree programs. Popular programs include business, engineering and the health professions.
About 43% of students take part in research or a scholarly project before they graduate. UTEP boasts more than $100 million in annual research expenditures and is ranked fifth in the state for federal research expenditures at a public university.
Students take part in 1 million hours of community service annually, as well as more than 200 clubs, Greek life and Division I athletics.
UTEP is one of the largest Hispanic-Serving Institutions in the country, with Hispanic students making up over 80% of the student body. Almost half of students are first-generation.
name: University of Texas, El Paso

description:
The University of Evansville is a private university in Evansville, IN that enhances its intimate community through hands-on learning experiences.
Students can choose from over 80 areas of study. Popular programs include exercise science, nursing and health services administration. The university launched the UE Music Conservatory in Fall 2021.
The university has a center called Harlaxton College in Gratham, England, as well as study abroad programs in over 50 countries. On campus, there are more than 120 student organizations, and about one-quarter of the student body is involved in Greek life.
Prospective students who visit campus are eligible for an annual $1,000 scholarship. The Aces Opportunity Grant guarantees that Indiana residents whose family’s adjusted gross income is less than $50,000 do not have to pay tuition out of pocket.
Approximately 91% of 2020 graduates were employed or in graduate school within six months of graduating.
name: University of Evansville

description:
Elizabethtown College is a nonsectarian liberal arts school in Elizabethtown, PA, a small town in Central Pennsylvania.
Elizabethtown has a rigorous core curriculum across eight disciplines, including classes in Western and Non-Western Cultural Heritage, Mathematics and Language.
There are three art galleries on campus, two of which are in Leffler Chapel, which also has an 840-seat auditorium.
Elizabethtown cheers on its men’s soccer team against rival Messiah College in a unique way—fans throw marshmallows on the field, calling the rivalry matchup ”The Marshmallow Game.”
Notable Elizabethtown alumni include Richard Bond, former CEO of Tyson Foods, and Bill Foster, former head coach of Duke University’s men’s basketball team.
name: Elizabethtown College

description:
Founded in 1890, the University of Central Oklahoma in Edmond, OK, is one of the state’s oldest higher education institutions.
The university offers over 100 undergraduate programs, including fully online degrees. UCO is home to the Forensic Science Institute, providing comprehensive training and research experiences for students in forensic science, one of the most popular majors. Other popular programs are in business, the health professions and liberal arts.
Campus is bustling with more than 200 student organizations, Greek life and Division II athletics. UCO is located about 20 minutes from downtown Oklahoma City, providing students with professional and extracurricular opportunities.
Automatic scholarships for incoming freshmen range from $1,000 to $2,000 annually. UCO offers a voluntary Tuition Lock Program for Oklahoma residents to lock in a tuition rate—set 5% above the tuition rate for the entry term—that will not be impacted by later increases in tuition costs.
Six months following graduation, 58% of the graduates from the class of 2020 are employed and 13% are continuing their education. 89% are staying in Oklahoma.
name: University of Central Oklahoma

description:
Situated in Alaska’s interior region, the University of Alaska, Fairbanks is a public institution with a dedication to research and polar bears.
UAF’s campus is just 120 miles south of the Arctic Circle.
Much of the school’s research is arctic, such as a recent analysis of a 17,000-year-old wooly mammoth fossil housed on campus.
The College of Fisheries and Ocean Sciences is one of UAF’s nine schools, educating future leaders in Alaska’s many rich fisheries.
Named after the local Native Alaskan word for polar bear, the UAF athletic teams compete as the Nanooks. Fitting for its Alaska location, ice hockey, rifle and skiing are among the Nanooks’ 10 sports.
name: University of Alaska, Fairbanks

description:
Union University is a private liberal arts school in Jackson, TN, affiliated with the Southern Baptist Convention. The university, located 80 miles east of Memphis and 120 miles west of Nashville, aims to promote development through a Christ-centered education and commitment to service.
There are 115 majors for students to choose from. Many students at the university pursue nursing or business.
Every year, the university holds a campus-wide service day when students, faculty and staff come together to community service projects at the school and at various church-affiliated and non-profit organizations.
At the university, 100% of students receive some form of financial aid. Union University offers merit scholarships of up to $16,000 and one scholarship that covers full tuition, room and board. There are also $1,000 scholarships for students from ethnic minority groups and students whose parents are ministers.
name: Union University (TN)

description:
Marymount University in Arlington, VA, is a private Catholic institution that prides itself on its tight-knit community and inquiry-based learning.
The university offers over 40 undergraduate majors through its Colleges of Business, Innovation, Leadership, and Technology; Health and Education; and Sciences and Humanities. Popular majors include nursing, business administration and information technology. Marymount is a member of the Consortium of Universities of the Washington Metropolitan Area, which allows students to take courses at any of the other 13 member institutions, including Georgetown University and The Catholic University of America.
Learning at Marymount doesn’t stop in the classroom. Undergraduates are encouraged to take part in research, and the university provides funding for travel to present at conferences. Annually, MU students provide more than 16,000 hours of service locally and globally.
Students can take part in more than 30 clubs and Division III sports. The university’s close proximity to Washington, D.C. provides students with a wealth of professional and cultural experiences.
Over 70% of students hail from the DMV area, and students of color comprise over half of undergraduates. Marymount is Virginia’s only Hispanic-serving institution. About 22% of undergraduates receive Pell Grants.
name: Marymount University

description:
Spanning 63 acres near the mountains in Helena, MT, Carroll College is Catholic liberal arts institution that aims to give students experiential learning as part of the college experience.
Carroll College offers 37 majors, including the ability for students to design their own major. Programs in health professions are the most popular, followed by biological sciences and business.
Any student can join the adventure and mountaineering program, where students do activities such as snowshoeing and fly-fishing in groups. The campus is close to Helena’s 75 miles of hiking and biking trails.
The campus ministry holds mass and adoration every day of the week. The organization also hosts retreats several times every year, as well as service trips in a few major cities.
About 99% of students receive some form of financial aid. Merit scholarships range from $16,000 to $32,000 on average. Additionally, students who graduated from a high school in Montana, Oregon or Idaho may be eligible for a scholarship between $2,000 and $10,000.
name: Carroll College

description:
The smallest of the three universities in the University of Illinois system, the University of Illinois at Springfield provides students with both individualized attention and the opportunities of a larger institution.
Undergraduates can choose from over 50 degrees across four colleges, as well as ​​almost 30 fully online degrees. The most popular majors are business administration, psychology and computer science.
UIS has approximately $7 million in research funding annually, and undergraduates can receive up to $1,000 from the university to assist with research costs.
Students take part in more than 85 clubs, Greek life and Division II athletics. UIS is located in the capital of Illinois, providing students with numerous extracurricular and professional experiences, especially in government and policy.
Within a year of graduation, about 44% of students from the class of 2020 are working full-time, and 47% are continuing their education.
name: University of Illinois at Springfield

description:
Known for its emphasis on the arts, Bennington College is a private liberal arts gem in Vermont.
Bennington does not have traditional dormitories, instead it primarily housing students in houses of 30-45 people, fostering a homey environment complete with fireplaces in common rooms.
More than half of Bennington undergraduates major in the visual and performing arts. Other popular majors are in literature, music and dance.
All Bennington students have internships related to their field of study, a majority of which take place during the six-week field work term between the fall and spring semesters.
Emmy Award-winning “Game of Thrones” actor Peter Dinklage graduated from Bennington in 1991. His 2012 commencement speech in which he encouraged graduates to give themselves permission to fail was named by NPR as one of the best commencement speeches ever.
name: Bennington College

description:
This Catholic Benedictine college with its main campus in Duluth, MN, has six other campuses across the state. The College of St. Scholastica has nearly doubled its total student body over the past decade due to increasing education available online.
There are about 75 majors available on campus for traditional students. There are also nine online undergraduate degrees available. Almost half of students are in the nursing program.
There are more than 60 clubs and organizations on campus. The CSS Saints play in 24 Division III teams.
The career services office and alumni association at Saint Scholastica offers services to all alumni regardless of how long ago they graduated.
More than 98% of students receive some form of financial aid. All students are automatically considered for merit scholarships of up to $26,000 per year, including a $2,500 scholarship for students who are Jewish. There are 14 additional scholarships for first-year students to apply for.
name: College of St. Scholastica

description:
Hawai’i Pacific University is the largest private university in the state and provides learning experiences in both city and serene settings.
Undergraduates can choose from over 30 programs. Popular majors include business administration, nursing and biology. In addition to its main campus in downtown Honolulu, which is the business and financial center of the Pacific, HPU has a suburban campus nearby in the foothills of O’ahu’s Ko’olau mountains.
HPU offers hands-on research and internship opportunities for students at the Oceanic Institute, its aquaculture research facility. Students can become scientific divers to complete underwater research.
The university is known for its diverse student body; more than half are students of color. Students come from all 50 states and 70 countries.
Former Hawaii Rep. and presidential candidate Tulsi Gabbard graduated from HPU.
name: Hawaii Pacific University

description:
Assumption University is a Catholic school in Worcester, MA, an hour drive from Boston.
As a small liberal arts college, the Assumption community is tight-knit, with 85% of students living on campus all four years.
Assumption officially changed its name from Assumption College to Assumption University in June 2020.
Human Services and Rehabilitation Studies is Assumption’s most popular major, which provides an educational foundation for students to pursue careers in health, disability and human service-related fields.
Notre Dame football coach Brian Kelly, who once coached softball at Assumption, leads Assumption’s list of notable alumni.
name: Assumption University

description:
Champlain College is a small, private institution in the vibrant college town of Burlington, VT, that offers career-focused majors.
Undergraduates can choose from over 30 majors in business, communication, education and information technology and sciences. Champlain is known for its Upside-Down Curriculum, which allows students to dive into their field of choice and take as many as six major classes during freshman year.
More than half of students study abroad. Champlain has two satellite campuses in Montreal, Canada and Dublin, Ireland. Over 80% of graduating seniors indicate that they completed one or more internship or professional work experience while at Champlain.
More than 95% of students receive scholarships, which the college invests more than $36 million in annually. The Count-On-It Financial Aid Guarantee ensures that the amount of aid awarded freshman year will not decline over time.
On average over the last five years, 93% of graduates were employed or continuing their education within six months after graduating.
name: Champlain College

description:
University of St Francis in Joliet, IL, is a Catholic liberal arts university focused on service and leadership.
Undergraduates can choose from over 50 majors. USF also offers online programs geared toward adults finishing their degree. Popular programs include the health professions, business and education.
As a Franciscan university, the university ministry is an integral part of campus life and offers retreats and missions both nationally and internationally for students of all faiths. Just under half of students identify as Catholic.
Students take part in over 40 clubs. USF is a short train ride from Chicago, which provides them with a wide range of extracurricular and professional opportunities.
Freshman scholarships range up to full tuition, and all incoming freshmen receive some form of aid. St. Francis gives out over $20 million in scholarships and grants.
name: University of St Francis

description:
Hendrix College is an intimate liberal arts college in central Arkansas that prioritizes experiential learning and community building.
Students can choose from over 30 majors, as well as pre-professional programs in engineering, health, law, ministry, social work and teaching. Popular programs include psychology, biochemistry and biology.
The Hendrix Odyssey Program ensures that students complete at least three hands-on learning experiences during their time at the college, including research and service. Student life includes taking part in some of the 70 clubs—but no Greek life. Although the college is related to the United Methodist Church, participation in religious life is voluntary, but encouraged.
All students receive financial assistance. The Hendrix Achievement-Based Scholarship awards at least $15,000 to high-achieving students. Competitive scholarships include the Hays Memorial Scholarship, which covers the cost of attendance, and the Provost Scholarship, which covers tuition.
About a third of graduates plan to attend graduate or professional school immediately after graduation.
name: Hendrix College

description:
A small Catholic school, St. John Fisher College is in Pittsford, N.Y., a suburb seven miles outside of Rochester.
Nearly a third of undergraduates major in nursing.
Thanks to the iFISHER: Next Generation Learning Initiative, all Fisher students received an iPad, keyboard case, and Apple Pencil, accelerating technology integration in the classroom.
Fisher recently placed sixth on Niche’s 2022 Best College Food in America list.
The Wegmans School of Nursing was established thanks to an $8 million gift in 2006 from Robert Wegman, former chairman of Rochester-based Wegmans Food Markets. Wegman also is the namesake of the Wegmans School of Pharmacy.
name: Saint John Fisher College

description:
Soka University of America is a private liberal arts college in Orange County, CA, founded on the Buddhist principles of peace, human rights and the sanctity of life.
Students earn a BA in the liberal arts, with concentrations including environmental studies, humanities, international studies, life sciences, and social and behavioral sciences.
Soka boasts intimate class sizes and a low student-to-faculty ratio of 8-to-1. International students make up over half of the student body.
Undergraduates are required to study abroad in their language of study for a semester during their third year at no extra cost.
Students whose family’s annual income is less than $60,000 will receive the Soka Opportunity Grant, which covers up to full tuition. Soka also offers a number of merit scholarships providing up to the cost of attendance.
name: Soka University of America

description:
Newman University in Wichita, KS, is a private university grounded in Catholic values and traditions.
Undergraduates can choose from over 30 programs across five schools, as well as pre-professional options. Popular majors include education, nursing and biology. In addition to its main campus, NU has outreach sites in Southeast Kansas, Western Kansas, Colorado Springs, CO, and Tulsa and Oklahoma City, OK.
The Newman Studies Program places an emphasis on active learning, and the curriculum includes cooperative education and internships with local businesses, schools and health care institutions. Students are encouraged to engage globally and can study abroad at Newman’s campus in Birmingham, UK.
Students can take part in over 30 clubs. As a Catholic institution, campus ministry is an important part of student life and offers retreats, Bible studies and community service opportunities.
Newman academic scholarships range from $12,000 to $16,000. The university also offers the prestigious St. John Henry Newman Scholarship, which covers full tuition.
name: Newman University

description:
Eastern Michigan University is a large public research university in Ypsilanti, MI, that has been serving the community for over 170 years.
EMU offers 200 majors and minors across five colleges. The Colleges of Arts and Sciences, Health and Human Services, and Business have the highest enrollment.
The university is home to six research centers. Undergraduates are encouraged to take part in research and can receive up to $2,000 to support their work.
The 880-acre campus has over 18 miles of walkways, including an art trail. EMU competes in the NCAA Division I, and EMU Theatre puts on upwards of six large-scale shows annually.
65% of the class of 2020 is employed, and 8% is continuing education. The majority—85%—remain in Michigan.
name: Eastern Michigan University

description:
Located in the heart of Southern California, Whittier College is a private liberal arts college with Quaker roots.
Whittier offers over 30 undergraduate majors, including a 3-2 engineering track (a B.A. and a B.S.) and pre-professional programs in the health sciences. Popular programs include business administration, biology, psychology and kinesiology.
Student life comprises more than 90 clubs and 10 societies, which are similar to fraternities and sororities. On average, some 20% students participate in community service. The college also offers fellowships to fund student research and other mentored experiences.
Students of color constitute almost 70% of the student body, and about half of undergraduates are Hispanic/Latino. The majority of students hail from California, and the Fall 2021 incoming class saw its largest number—90—of international students in Whittier history.
Every admitted student will be considered for a John Greenleaf Whittier Scholarship, worth $15,000 to $36,000 annually. The California Community College Advantage program guarantees admission and a reduced tuition for transfer students from California community colleges.
name: Whittier College

description:
The University of Wisconsin, Whitewater is a public university in the UW system with specializations in business and education.
Undergraduates can choose from over 50 majors. The Colleges of Business and Economics; Letters and Sciences; and Education and Professional Studies have the highest enrollments. UW-Whitewater also has a campus in Rock County that has a guaranteed transfer program to other UW institutions.
Over one-third of undergraduates are first-generation students, and the majority of students hail from Wisconsin.
UW-Whitewater has the lowest cost of tuition, room and board and fees among the four-year campuses in the UW System. The university also has a textbook rental program that covers up to 95% of course materials.
99% of graduates are employed or in graduate school following graduation. Over 90% of students remain in the region following graduation.
name: University of Wisconsin-Whitewater

description:
Elmhurst University, located in a suburb right outside of Chicago, is celebrating 150 years of combining a tight-knit academic community with the experiences of a vibrant city.
Undergraduates can choose from more than 70 majors and 15 pre-professional programs. Popular programs include psychology, nursing and business administration.
Elmhurst is home to the E-celerator, an entrepreneurship center that hosts an entrepreneur in residence. Students can also study abroad in over 40 locations.
True to its mission as a United Church of Christ institution, there are 2,000 international and domestic service projects, for which the university provides $2,000 Common Good grants.
Incoming freshmen are automatically considered for scholarships ranging from $10,000 to $22,000. The university also offers talent scholarships for music, art and theater, as well as competition-based awards for first-generation students and students committed to service.
name: Elmhurst University

description:
Barry University is a Catholic liberal arts institution in Miami, FL, that utilizes its diverse location with thriving industries to enhance the student experience.
BU offers over 100 degree programs. Popular majors include business, nursing and biology. Barry also offers classes in locations across Florida and in the Bahamas.
Barry offers study abroad opportunities in more than 20 countries. On campus, students are minutes away from beaches and can take part in more than 60 student organizations, including Greek life.
Over 60% of students are people of color. Barry is designated as a Hispanic-serving institution, with over 30% of the student body identifying as such.
All students receive some type of financial aid. Merit scholarships range from $7,500 to $19,000 annually. Students who graduated from Catholic Florida high schools are eligible for a full-tuition award, and the university offers other scholarships based on leadership and talents.
name: Barry University

description:
Taylor is a non-denominational Christian liberal arts school in Upland, IN, that shapes its educational mission through building faith.
Taylor’s liberal arts core curriculum emphasizes spiritual foundations, physical health, the fine arts, civic engagement, public speaking and math and sciences.
Students sign the “Life Together Covenant,” which requires students to live by Biblical responsibilities and forbids homosexual behavior, premarital sex and drunkenness. Taylor doesn’t monitor chapel attendance, but students often attend services.
Hundreds of students study abroad, and can earn credit as short-term missionaries to U.S. cities.
Academic awards range up to $16,000, and other merit scholarships are awarded for arts, athletics and music. Indiana students are eligible for special scholarships.
Approximately 98% of graduates were employed or in graduate school within six months of graduation.
name: Taylor University

description:
Dominican University of California, located in the San Francisco Bay Area, is a close-knit student body that has served the community for over 130 years.
Students can choose from over 60 majors. Over half of students are enrolled in the School of Health and Natural Sciences.
Students take part in community service through service-learning courses, completing more than 8,000 hours annually. Students are also required to complete a signature work—either research or a creative or scholarly project.
The park-like campus is tranquil and cultivates an intimate community among its 1,000-plus student body, but students also have access to the big city-feel of San Francisco, which is just a half hour away.
The student body is diverse, with about 68% identifying as a student of color. About one-third of students are Pell Grant-eligible, and 23% are first generation.
name: Dominican University of California

description:
Worcester State University in Worcester, MA, has grown from a teacher training school to a comprehensive public institution with programs spanning from biomedical sciences, business, humanities, and behavioral sciences to the health professions.
Students can choose from 60 undergraduate majors and minors. Popular programs include the health professions, business and criminal justice.
WSU offers over 60 study abroad programs and partnerships. Students can study abroad on short-term faculty trips or up to a year.
The university calls Worcester—the second largest city in Massachusetts—home. Students can take part in more than 30 organizations and NCAA Division III sports.
Incoming WSU students are automatically considered for merit aid. Over 4,000 students receive financial aid, and the average award package is over $10,000.
name: Worcester State University

description:
Regis University is a private Jesuit Catholic school in Denver, CO, with a reputation for educating veterans.
The university’s main campus is in Northwest Denver, but Regis also operates campuses in nearby Thornton, CO, and Greenwood Village, CO.
Regis is one of the most veteran-friendly colleges in the country, with 15% of the student body identifying as a veteran, active duty military or military reserve.
The Center for the Study of War Experience further solidifies Regis’ connection with veterans, conducting oral history interviews with those involved in military conflict.
Some 91% of Regis graduates reported employment within six months of graduation, with the most common employment areas being healthcare, education and government.
name: Regis University

description:
Eastern Washington is a large, public university in Cheney, WA, that aims to bring quality education to traditional and nontraditional college students in the Inland Northwest.
Undergraduates at Eastern Washington can choose from over 100 majors, including one of the few industrial robotics and engineering programs in the Northwest. About 30% of undergraduates opt to major in a STEM field.
About three quarters of EWU students receive financial aid, and just under half graduate debt-free. Each year, the school gives out $140 million in aid, and nearly $6 million in scholarships.
The EPIC adventures program makes the great outdoors accessible for EWU students. The school also maintains a research center in the nearby Turnbull National Wildlife Refuge.
Notable alumni include comic book creator Todd McFarlane and Olympic rifle champion Launi Meili.
name: Eastern Washington University

description:
A midsize, public university in Marquette, MI, NMU is the largest institution of higher education in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula, and aims to foster an active environment for students’ bodies and minds.
NMU offers 170 degree programs, including robust offerings in engineering and education. The “First Year Experience” puts students into small cohorts of peers pursuing the same major.
Students at NMU make the most of the Upper Peninsula’s natural beauty with 96 miles of cross country skiing trails, mountain biking on the Keweenaw Peninsula and a 1,450 square foot climbing wall.
The school offers a number of merit scholarships, including the Wildcat Merit Scholarships, which are determined by high school GPA and are available for all students regardless of Michigan residence.
Notable alumni include former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz and football coaches Tom Izzo and Steve Mariucci.
name: Northern Michigan University

description:
Trevecca Nazarene is a small, Christian liberal arts college in Nashville, TN, that aims to provide a holistic education and create student leaders within the Nazarene Methodist tradition.
While Trevecca is home to nearly 1,500 traditional college students, it enrolls far more in its graduate and continuing education programs.
Undergraduates at Trevecca can pursue 118 majors, including programs in Christian ministry and exercise science.
Nearly all students at Trevecca receive financial aid or a scholarship. The school offers a number of merit-based awards based on GPA and ACT scores, including the full tuition McClurkan Scholars award.
name: Trevecca Nazarene University

description:
A liberal arts college founded by the Moravian Church in America, Moravian University spans 85 acres in Bethlehem, PA, about 60 miles north of Philadelphia.
Moravian University offers more than 70 majors. Nursing and other health fields are the most populous programs, closely followed by business.
Through the Student Opportunities for Academic Research (SOAR), the university gives stipends to students in any major who pursue faculty-led research or a creative project.
About 98% of Moravian students are employed or enroll in graduate school within ten months of graduating. And around 99% of students receive some form of financial aid.
There are more than 60 clubs and organizations for students to join, including nine different honor societies. About 20% of students are members of the university’s five fraternity and three sorority chapters.
name: Moravian University

description:
West Texas A&M is a midsize, public university in Canyon, TX, that aims to foster a spirit of innovation and community service in its student body.
Students at West Texas A&M can choose from 60 undergraduate majors, including a large number of programs in agricultural sciences and education.
The West Texas Buffaloes play in 14 NCAA D2 sports. Students can also get involved with 83 student groups, including Greek life, professional interest and cultural clubs.
Since 2008, the school has upheld the “Buff Promise,” where in-state tuition and fees are covered for Texas families that have a household income of $80,000 or lower. Every year the school gives out $5 million in scholarships.
name: West Texas A & M University

description:
SUNY College at Plattsburgh is a public college serving primarily New York residents for over 130 years.
SUNY Plattsburgh's three schools—Arts and Science, Business and Economics, and Education, Health and Human Services—offer 60 degree programs. Business, the health professions and communications are popular programs.
Students can engage in more than 100 organizations. Plattsburgh is about an hour away from Montreal, Lake Placid and Burlington, VT. Over one-third of freshmen identify as students of color.
Almost 90% of students hail from New York. Out-of-state students can receive an annual grant of $7,500.
About 63% of the class of 2020 is employed, and about 11% is continuing education.
name: SUNY College at Plattsburgh

description:
Georgia College & State University in Milledgeville, GA, is a public liberal arts university that places emphasis on leadership and experiential learning.
Students can choose from more than 40 majors across four colleges: the College of Arts and Sciences, the J. Whitney Bunting College of Business, the John H. Lounsbury College of Education and the College of Health Sciences. Popular programs include exercise science, nursing and business.
The liberal arts curriculum requires students to take part in five experiences, including studying abroad and participating in research or community service. More than 600 students are involved in leadership programs at the university, which provides workshops, retreats and scholarship opportunities.
The college has over 150 student organizations, including Greek life, and more than 2,000 students belong to one of 29 chapters. The college is located about two hours away from Atlanta, the state’s capital.
The President’s Scholarship Competition is a day-long interview process, and awards range from $3,000 to $6,000 annually, as well as stipends for research and studying abroad.
name: Georgia College & State University

description:
Located 35 miles east of Los Angeles in La Verne, CA, University of La Verne is a private school that offers specialized and accelerated programs for nontraditional students.
More than 40% of traditional students at ULV are the first in their family to attend college. The university hosts a peer mentoring program for incoming first-generation students, as well as workshops and community recognition days.
There are more than 50 majors at ULV, with the most popular programs being business and psychology.
There are 80 student clubs at the university, as well as 21 Division III sports teams and six fraternity and sorority chapters.
Over 70% of students receive some form of financial aid. For the 2020-21 academic year, the annual institutional financial aid awarded was $52.5 million.
name: University of La Verne

description:
The Evergreen State College is a unique public liberal arts and sciences college in Olympia, WA.
Rather than declaring a major, students can choose from over 40 interdisciplinary fields of study to earn either a Bachelor of Arts or Bachelor of Science. Evergreen also offers programs in Tacoma for working students, as well as a Native Pathways Program for students who are involved within Native American or Indigenous communities and culture.
Evergreen calls a lush 1,000-acre campus home, full of trails, forests and a beach on the Puget Sound. The college has an unusual mascot that represents its unique curriculum—a geoduck, or a burrowing clam, named Speedy.
Over 80% of students hail from Washington. About 28% are first-generation students, and almost half receive Pell Grants. Students of color make up one-third of the student body.
One year after graduation, 90% are employed, in graduate school or engaging in service.
name: The Evergreen State College

description:
A unique and highly arts-focused school, Pratt Institute has Brooklyn and Manhattan campuses and an affiliate campus in upstate Utica, NY.
Pratt offers 14 undergraduate degree programs, all focused on the arts, design and architecture/construction.
At Pratt, there are six traditional residence halls and “The Townhouses,” which house six students each in nearby remodeled Brooklyn historic row houses.
Students in the School of Art and School of Design spend their first year studying in Pratt Foundation, a series of studio classes with the same cluster of 15 students that immerses students into the school.
Pratt has produced many of the top creative minds, including Academy Award-winning actor Robert Redford and William Van Allen, architect of New York City’s iconic Chrysler Building.
name: Pratt Institute

description:
A progressive liberal arts school, Hampshire College is in the college town of Amherst, MA.
Instead of letter grades, Hampshire professors give students portfolio and narrative evaluations rather than grades of their performance in class.
Hampshire students design their own curriculums, and a multidisciplinary education is strongly encouraged.
Hampshire was among the first schools in the country to be SAT or ACT optional and are test blind in their admissions process.
Along with Amherst, Smith, and Mount Holyoke Colleges, and the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, Hampshire makes up the Five College Consortium. Consortium students can take classes, join clubs or use libraries at partner institutions.
Despite the school’s size, Hampshire has produced numerous big names, including Black Panther actress Lupita Nyong’o and documentary filmmaker Ken Burns.
name: Hampshire College

description:
Only five decades old, Lynn University is a small private school in Boca Raton, Florida with an international presence.
Lynn’s 115-acre palm tree-lined campus matches the country club vibes of its home city. The upcoming 20,000-square foot Snyder Center for Health and Wellness will feature indoor and outdoor fitness spaces and mental health services.
The university was founded as a two-year women’s college in 1962, and only began offering bachelor’s degrees in 1986.
Lynn is global: 17% of students are international, hailing from 101 countries.
In 2012, Lynn hosted the final presidential debate between President Barack Obama and Senator Mitt Romney.
name: Lynn University

description:
Rollins College is a private liberal arts school in Winter Park, FL with a country club-esque campus where students take advantage of personalized majors to fit their individual goals.
The campus is located on Lake Virginia, complete with a lakeside swimming pool with lounge chairs and a dozen tennis courts.
Rollins prides itself on offering “cool classes,” with unique course topics includings children book writing, the history of piracy and sports analytics.
Each spring on a day that is “too pretty to have class,” Rollins celebrates Fox Day by cancelling classes, allowing students to fully enjoy the picturesque campus.
Fred Rogers, beloved host of “Mr. Rogers Neighborhood,” is a Rollins alumnus. This October, Rollins will unveil a 7-foot, 3,000-pound statue of Mr. Rogers.
name: Rollins College

description:
About five miles from downtown Memphis, Christian Brothers University is a small private Catholic school with an urban but traditional 75-acre campus.
True to its name, CBU was originally an all-male institution, but women have been admitted since 1970. Today, the school is 50% female.
CBU has a 11-to-1 student-to-faculty ratio and the university strongly emphasizes the small classroom experience.
CBU is located within 15 minutes of numerous Memphis landmarks, including the National Civil Rights Museum, the Memphis Zoo and Graceland.
Graduates of CBU tend to stay close to their alma mater, as 83% of alumni remain in the Memphis metropolitan area after graduation.
name: Christian Brothers University

description:
The oldest continuously operating college in South Texas (just 40 miles from the beaches of Corpus Christi and 120 miles from the Mexican border), Texas A&M University-Kingsville gives a STEM-focused education to its 6,000 undergraduate students.
Nearly three quarters of Texas A&M-Kingsville's student body identifies as Hispanic, qualifying the university as a Hispanic Serving Institution.
About a quarter of students major in engineering. The Frank H. Dotterweich College of Engineering offers 10 majors, including Electrical Engineering and Natural Gas Engineering.
Actress Eva Longoria was a Kinesiology major at Texas A&M-Kingsville, only deciding to pursue acting instead of a career in physical therapy during her senior year.
name: Texas A&M University, Kingsville

description:
Founded in 1870, the University of Akron is a large, public school in Akron, OH, a 40-minute drive from Cleveland.
Akron’s Research Foundation provides numerous resources to budding entrepreneurs, offering funding sources, office space and mentorship.
Among Akron’s eight colleges is the School of Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering. The unique school was established in the early 1900s when Akron was known as the “Rubber Capital of the world." It offers minors and research opportunities to rubber-minded undergraduates.
NBA star and Akron legend LeBron James is a major benefactor of the university, commemorated by Akron’s LeBron James Family Foundation School of Education.
Notable Akron alumni include former NFL star Jason Taylor and actress Yvette Nicole Brown.
name: University of Akron

description:
Salve Regina University is a small Catholic university in Newport, RI, that emphasizes the liberal arts, universal justice and the religious tradition of the Sisters of Mercy.
The university’s 80-acre oceanfront campus captures Newport’s historic beauty. Campus spans seven 19th century estates, including Ochre Court, a Gilded Age mansion and now serves as the school’s main administrative building.
Salve Regina’s Pell Center for International Relations and Public Policy is named for Senator Claiborne Pell, creator of the Pell Grant program.
98% of Salve Regina graduates were employed or pursuing higher education within 6 months of graduating.
Actress Betty Hutton received her master’s degree in Psychology from Salve Regina after her acting days were over.
name: Salve Regina University

description:
Founded in 1875, Indiana University of Pennsylvania is a public school in Indiana, PA, a small city in western Pennsylvania. Indiana University emphasizes research and personalized learning.
Undergraduates at IUP can choose from more than 120 degree programs. Business administration, criminology, marketing and nursing are among the most popular majors.
IUP’s main campus spans 354 acres, including a 280 acre recreation park. The school also operates three satellite campuses across the region in Freeport, PA, eastern Pittsburgh, and Punxsutawney, PA.
Living-Learning Communities are popular at IUP. Topics for the communities include Health and Wellness, Social Justice and Civic Engagement, the LGBTQIA+ Community and the Cook Honors College.
YouTube co-founder Chad Hurley is an IUP alumnus.
name: Indiana University of Pennsylvania

description:
A midsize Catholic university with campuses in Erie, PA, and Ruskin, FL, Gannon works to mold its students into global citizens well-versed in the liberal arts and professional studies.
Students at Gannon can choose from 66 undergraduate majors, as well as a large number of certificates and accelerated master’s programs.
Gannon offers a several merit-based scholarships, including the full tuition Presidential Scholarship, as well as several others based on competitive strength in different disciplines. The school offers over $37 million in aid annually.
Students can join more than 100 clubs and organizations. The TRAVEL program gives students the opportunity to take transformative short and long-term trips abroad.
Gannon athletes play in NCAA D2 sports in the Pennsylvania State Athletic Conference.
name: Gannon University

description:
The flagship of Montana’s public university system, the University of Montana is a midsize research university in the lively college town of Missoula.
UM offers more than 70 undergraduate programs, including a large number of programs at the W.A. Franke College of Forestry and Conservation. It’s one of few institutions to offer programs in Central and Southwest Asian studies.
There are a large number of research centers on campus, including the recently-established American Indian Research and Policy Institute. In 2020 the school received a $10 million grant to study the health impact of climate change and its effects.
The Montana Grizzlies play in the NCAA D1 Big Sky Conference.
Notable alumni include Jeannette Rankin, the first woman elected to Congress, actor JK Simmons and influential US Senator Mike Mansfield.
name: The University of Montana

description:
Affiliated with the Presbyterian Church, Whitworth University is a private college in Spokane, WA.
Whitworth students enjoy the benefits of a small school experience, as 84% of classes have less than 30 students and the student-to-faculty ratio is 12 to 1.
Biology is one of the most popular majors at Whitworth, and majors can study human cadavers or live animals housed in Whitworth’s Robinson Science Hall.
Since June 1, 2021, Scott McQuilkin has served as the university’s interim president, and a search for Whitworth’s 19th president is currently underway.
Among the Class of 2020, 55% of graduates studied abroad. Faculty-led study abroad programs take place from Costa Rica to Tanzania.
name: Whitworth University

description:
Augustana University in Sioux Falls, SD, one of the oldest institutions affiliated with the Lutheran Church, is committed to hands-on undergraduate experiences.
The university offers over 60 undergraduate majors and 15 pre-professional programs. Popular programs include nursing, biology and business administration. Augustana has a sister college, Augustana College, in Rock Island, IL.
Experiential learning is a hallmark of the Augustana experience; 98% of the Class of 2020 graduates took part in internships, clinicals, studying abroad and volunteering. The university provides approximately $250,000 annually to fund these experiences, many of which occur during the one-month January term.
Even with no Greek life, the campus is bustling with over 100 student organizations, including Division III athletics and campus ministry opportunities.
From the Class of 2020, 97% of graduates are employed in their major or chosen field. Health, education and management are among the top fields of occupation.
name: Augustana University

description:
A small, Lutheran liberal arts college in the town of Decorah, IA, Luther teaches its students to seek truth, embrace diversity and serve as stewards of the natural world.
Luther offers 38 undergraduate majors, most of which are also available as minors.
All Luther students take “Paideia,” a series of seminar courses that dig into critical inquiry, ethics and moral investigations. Students can participate in special January terms domestically or abroad.
Luther’s nature preserve spans nearly 700 acres with 8 miles of trails. Students can explore the outdoors, or join one of Luther’s dozens of clubs and organizations, like the Norwegian-affinity club, “Norskklubb.”
Notable Luther alumni include the late Marriott International CEO Arne Sorenson and former US ambassador Callista Gingrich.
name: Luther College

description:
Coe College is a liberal arts school in Cedar Rapids, Iowa with a strong focus on writing and athletics.
Since 1986, Coe’s Writing Across the Curriculum program has been a signature of the university’s academic plan, ensuring students in all studies spend a significant amount of time writing.
Coe’s multidisciplinary approach extends beyond writing; 40% of students double major and graduate in four years.
The Coe College Kohawks compete in the Division III American Rivers Conference, and 35% of the student body plays on one of the Kohawks’ varsity teams.
All Coe students are guaranteed an internship, research or study abroad experience.
name: Coe College

description:
St Francis is a small, Catholic liberal arts college in Brooklyn, NY, that aims to cultivate leadership in its students and instill the teachings of St. Francis of Assisi.
There are more than 70 majors and minors offered at St Francis, ranging from liberal arts programs in philosophy and religion to practical degrees in radiography and accounting.
The core curriculum at St Francis requires students to take courses focused on skills like writing and quantitative reasoning, as well as subject areas like world heritage and humanistic & creative expression.
St Francis offers a number of merit based scholarships, as well as small scholarships for students who attended faith-based highschools. The school gives out more than $20 million in institutional scholarships a year.
name: St. Francis College
